paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and ADAM enter.

paragraphs.original: As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand crowns, and, as thou sayest, charged my brother on his blessing to breed me well. And there begins my sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and report speaks goldenly of his profit. For my part, he keeps me rustically at home or, to speak more properly, stays me here at home unkept; for call you that "keeping" for a gentleman of my birth that differs not from the stalling of an ox? His horses are bred better, for, besides that they are fair with their feeding, they are taught their manage and, to that end, riders dearly hired. But I, his brother, gain nothing under him but growth, for the which his animals on his dunghills are as much bound to him as I. Besides this nothing that he so plentifully gives me, the something that nature gave me his countenance seems to take from me. He lets me feed with his hinds, bars me the place of a brother, and, as much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my education. This is it, Adam, that grieves me, and the spirit of my father, which I think is within me, begins to mutiny against this servitude. I will no longer endure it, though yet I know no wise remedy how to avoid it.
paragraphs.translated:
I remember, Adam, that's
exactly why my father only left me a thousand crowns in his will. And as you know, my father commanded my brother, Oliver, to make sure that I was brought up well - and that's where my sadness begins. Oliver keeps my brother Jaques away at school, and everyone says he's doing extremely well there. But he keeps me at home in the country - to be precise, he keeps me stuck at home but doesn't support me. I ask you, is this any way to treat a gentleman as nobly born as I am, to pen me in like an ox? His horses get treated better than I do - at least he feeds them and trains them properly, and spends a lot of money on trainers for them. All I've gained from his care is weight, which makes me as indebted to him as his animals on the manure pile are. He gives me plenty of nothing, and takes away everything else, letting me eat with his servants, refusing me what's owed me as his brother, and ruining my good birth with a poor education. This is what angers me, Adam. My father's temper and spirit, which I think I share, makes me want to mutiny against my brother's tyranny. I won't stand for it any longer, though I haven't yet figured out how to revolt.
exactly

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVER
paragraphs.translated: OLIVER enters.

paragraphs.original: Yonder comes my master, your brother.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes my master, your brother.

paragraphs.original: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will shake me up.
paragraphs.translated: Go hide, Adam, and you'll hear how he abuses me.

paragraphs.original: Now, sir, what make you here?
paragraphs.translated:
Hey, you! What are you
making here?
making

paragraphs.original: Nothing. I am not taught to make anything.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing. I've never been taught how to make anything.

paragraphs.original: What mar you then, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, what are you messing up?

paragraphs.original: Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that which God made, a poor unworthy brother of yours, with idleness.
paragraphs.translated:
I'm helping you mess up one of God's creations - your poor, unworthy brother - by having him do nothing.
you

paragraphs.original: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, sir, find something better to do and get lost for a while.

paragraphs.original: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them? What prodigal portion have I spent that I should come to such penury?
paragraphs.translated:
Should I tend your pigs and eat husks with them? When did I
waste so much money that I ended up this poor?
waste

paragraphs.original: Know you where you are, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know where you are, sir?

paragraphs.original: O sir, very well: here in your orchard.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, very well - I'm here in your orchard.

paragraphs.original: Know you before whom, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know whom you're talking to?

paragraphs.original: Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I know you are my eldest brother, and in the gentle condition of blood you should so know me. The courtesy of nations allows you my better, in that you are the first-born, but the same tradition takes not away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt us. I have as much of my father in me as you, albeit, I confess, your coming before me is nearer to his reverence.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, better than you know me. I know you're my oldest brother, and deserve more respect. But we're in the same family, so you should acknowledge that I am a gentleman too. According to custom, as the first-born you are my superior. But it's not customary to treat me like I'm not even a gentleman, even if there were twenty brothers between you and me. I have as much of our father in me as you do, though I admit you're closer to him and matter more because you're older.

paragraphs.original:
What, boy! (strikes him)
(strikes him)

Come, come, elder brother, you are too young in this. (seizes him)
(seizes him)
Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?
paragraphs.translated: What, you dare put your hands on me, villain?

paragraphs.original: I am no villain. I am the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys. He was my father, and he is thrice a villain that says such a father begot villains. Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so. Thou hast railed on thyself.
paragraphs.translated: I'm no villain. I'm the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys, and anyone who claims my father's sons are villains is a villain himself. If you weren't my brother, I'd leave this hand of mine on your neck until I'd pulled out your tongue for talking like this. You've only insulted yourself.

paragraphs.original: Sweet masters, be patient. For your father's remembrance, be at accord.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, calm down. For the sake of your father's memory, make peace.

paragraphs.original: Let me go, I say.
paragraphs.translated: Let me go, I say.

paragraphs.original: I will not till I please. You shall hear me. My father charged you in his will to give me good education. You have trained me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all gentlemanlike qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in me, and I will no longer endure it. Therefore allow me such exercises as may become a gentleman, or give me the poor allottery my father left me by testament. With that I will go buy my fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: I won't until I'm ready. You will listen to me. My father instructed you in his will to give me a good education. But you've raised me as a peasant, hiding from me what I needed to become a gentleman. My father's spirit is growing in me, and I won't take this any longer. Either give me the freedom to act like someone of my own rank or give me my share of the inheritance, so that I can seek my fortune elsewhere.

paragraphs.original: And what wilt thou do - beg when that is spent? Well, sir, get you in. I will not long be troubled with you. You shall have some part of your will. I pray you leave me.
paragraphs.translated: And what are you going to do after you've spent your money? Beg? Well, sir, go inside. I'm not going to be bothered by you for long. You'll get some of what you want. Now please leave me alone.

paragraphs.original: I will no further offend you than becomes me for my good.
paragraphs.translated: I won't bother you any more than necessary.

paragraphs.original: Get you with him, you old dog.
Is "old dog" my reward? Most true, I have lost my teeth in your service. God be with my old master. He would not have spoke such a word.
paragraphs.translated: Is that my reward - to be called "old dog?" Well, it's true, I've served this family so long I've gotten old and toothless, like a dog. God bless my old master. He would never have spoken to me like this.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and ADAM exit.

paragraphs.original: Is it even so? Begin you to grow upon me? I will physic your rankness and yet give no thousand crowns neither. - Holla, Dennis!
paragraphs.translated: Is that how it's going to be? Are you starting to challenge me? I'll cure you of your insolence, and I'm not going to give you a thousand crowns, either! - Hey, Dennis!

paragraphs.original: Enter DENNIS
paragraphs.translated: DENNIS enters.

paragraphs.original: Calls your Worship?
paragraphs.translated: Did you call for me, your Worship?

paragraphs.original: Was not Charles, the duke's wrestler, here to speak with me?
paragraphs.translated: Wasn't Charles, the duke's wrestler, here to speak with me?

paragraphs.original: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes access to you.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, he's here at the door right now and asks to see you.

paragraphs.original: Call him in.
paragraphs.translated: Call him in.

paragraphs.original: Exit DENNIS
paragraphs.translated: DENNIS exits.

paragraphs.original: 'Twill be a good way, and tomorrow the wrestling is.
paragraphs.translated: I have a good plan. And tomorrow is the wrestling match.

paragraphs.original: Enter CHARLES
paragraphs.translated: CHARLES enters.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow to your Worship.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, sir.

paragraphs.original: Good Monsieur Charles, what's the new news at the new court?
paragraphs.translated: Good Mr. Charles! Tell me, what's the latest news at the new court?

paragraphs.original: There's no news at the court, sir, but the old news. That is, the old duke is banished by his younger brother the new duke, and three or four loving lords have put themselves into voluntary exile with him, whose lands and revenues enrich the new duke. Therefore he gives them good leave to wander.
paragraphs.translated: No news but the old news: the old Duke Senior has been banished by his younger brother, the new Duke Frederick. A few loyal lords have gone into exile with Duke Senior, and given up their lands and money to Frederick - so he's happy enough to have them leave.

paragraphs.original: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke's daughter, be banished with her father?
paragraphs.translated: Can you tell me whether Rosalind, Duke Senior's daughter, has also been banished?

paragraphs.original: Oh, no, for the duke's daughter her cousin so loves her, being ever from their cradles bred together, that she would have followed her exile or have died to stay behind her. She is at the court, and no less beloved of her uncle than his own daughter, and never two ladies loved as they do.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, no. Duke Frederick's daughter, Celia, grew up with Rosalind, and Celia loves her cousin so much that she would have either followed her into exile or died of grief. Rosalind has stayed at court, where Duke Frederick loves her like his own daughter. No two women ever loved each other like they do.

paragraphs.original: Where will the old duke live?
paragraphs.translated: Where will the old duke live?

paragraphs.original: They say he is already in the Forest of Arden, and a many merry men with him; and there they live like the old Robin Hood of England. They say many young gentlemen flock to him every day and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the golden world.
paragraphs.translated:
They say he's already in the Forest of Arden. He has many cheerful men with him, and they live like Robin Hood and his outlaws. People say that new batches of young men flock there every day, and that they all pass the time without a care, like people did in the
Golden Age.
Golden Age

paragraphs.original: What, you wrestle tomorrow before the new duke?
paragraphs.translated: So, are you going to wrestle before the new duke tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you with a matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition to come in disguised against me to try a fall. Tomorrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit, and he that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well. Your brother is but young and tender, and, for your love I would be loath to foil him, as I must for my own honor if he come in. Therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint you withal, that either you might stay him from his intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into, in that it is a thing of his own search and altogether against my will.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed I do, sir, and I've come to let you in on a certain problem. I've been informed by certain sources I can't disclose that your younger brother Orlando plans to fight me in disguise. Tomorrow, sir, I'm fighting for my reputation, and any man who gets away without a broken bone or two is an exceptional wrestler indeed. Your brother is young and inexperienced, and because of my affection for you, I'd hate to crush him - though I'd have to, if he challenged me. I'm telling you all this out of affection for you, so you can either keep him from carrying out his plans or prepare to accept his disgrace, which will be his own fault, not mine.

paragraphs.original: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which thou shalt find I will most kindly requite. I had myself notice of my brother's purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it; but he is resolute. I'll tell thee, Charles: it is the stubbornest young fellow of France, full of ambition, an envious emulator of every man's good parts, a secret and villainous contriver against me his natural brother. Therefore use thy discretion. I had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger. And thou wert best look to 't, for if thou dost him any slight disgrace or if he do not mightily grace himself on thee, he will practice against thee by poison, entrap thee by some treacherous device and never leave thee till he hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other. For I assure thee - and almost with tears I speak it - there is not one so young and so villainous this day living. I speak but brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.
paragraphs.translated: Charles, I thank you for your loyalty to me, and you'll see that I'll reward you. I'd heard about my brother's plan and have been subtly trying to change his mind, but he's determined. I tell you, Charles, he's the stubbornest young fellow in France: overly ambitious, jealous of other people's good qualities, and a traitor against me, his own blood brother. So use your discretion. I'd be just as happy if you broke his neck as his finger. And you'd better be careful, because if you embarrass him at all - in fact, if he doesn't beat you thoroughly - he'll come after you and won't leave you alone till he's poisoned you or trapped you - killed you, in other words, one way or another. It brings me to tears to say this, but there isn't another person alive who is so young and at the same time so wicked. Because he's my brother, I have to take his side. But if I really laid him bare, I'd have to weep and hang my head, and you would not believe me, his behavior is so shocking.

paragraphs.original: I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he come tomorrow, I'll give him his payment. If ever he go alone again, I'll never wrestle for prize more. And so God keep your Worship.
paragraphs.translated: I'm very glad I came to see you. If he shows up tomorrow, I'll give him what's coming to him. If he can manage to walk after our fight, I'll never wrestle for money again. Farewell, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, good Charles.
paragraphs.translated: Take care, Charles.

paragraphs.original: Exit CHARLES
paragraphs.translated: CHARLES exits.

paragraphs.original: Now will I stir this gamester. I hope I shall see an end of him, for my soul - yet I know not why - hates nothing more than he. Yet he's gentle, never schooled and yet learned, full of noble device, of all sorts enchantingly beloved, and indeed so much in the heart of the world and especially of my own people, who best know him, that I am altogether misprized. But it shall not be so long; this wrestler shall clear all. Nothing remains but that I kindle the boy thither, which now I'll go about.
paragraphs.translated: Now it's time to get this playboy brother of mine all worked up. I hope I'll see the end of him soon - I don't know why, but I hate nothing in the world as much as him, though he's an upstanding guy. He's never gone to school but he's smart, with good values, and everyone is delighted by him and loves him, especially my subjects, who know him the best. They love him, and therefore they despise me. But not for long; Charles will take care of everything. All I have to do is get Orlando to fight, which I'll do now.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND
paragraphs.translated: CELIA and ROSALIND enter.

paragraphs.original: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
paragraphs.translated: Please, Rosalind, my sweet cousin - be happy.

paragraphs.original: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of, and would you yet I were merrier? Unless you could teach me to forget a banished father, you must not learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: Dear Celia - I already look much happier than I feel, but you want me to look even happier? Unless you can also teach me how to forget my banished father, you shouldn't try to teach me how to be happy.

paragraphs.original: Herein I see thou lov'st me not with the full weight that I love thee. If my uncle, thy banished father, had banished thy uncle, the duke my father, so thou hadst been still with me, I could have taught my love to take thy father for mine. So wouldst thou, if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously tempered as mine is to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, by this I can see that you don't love me as much as I love you. If your father had banished my father, I could have learned to love your father as my own, as long as I still had you. You'd do the same, if your love for me were as true as mine for you.
your

paragraphs.original: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'll just forget the difficulties of my situation, in order to focus on the happiness of yours.

paragraphs.original: You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is like to have, and, truly, when he dies, thou shalt be his heir, for what he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I will render thee again in affection. By mine honor I will, and when I break that oath, let me turn monster. Therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.
paragraphs.translated: You know I'm my father's only child, and he isn't likely to have another. And when he dies, you will inherit his fortune - because whatever he took from your father by force, I will return to you as affection. I swear I will, and if I ever break my promise let me turn into a monster. So please, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be happy.

paragraphs.original: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports. Let me see - what think you of falling in love?
paragraphs.translated: From now on I will, cousin, and I'll think of all kinds of games for us. Let me see - what do you think about falling in love?

paragraphs.original: Marry, I prithee do, to make sport withal, but love no man in good earnest, nor no further in sport neither than with safety of a pure blush thou mayst in honor come off again.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, please do, so we can have a good laugh about it. But don't fall in love for real, and don't take the game too far. You want to get out of it easily, and with your honor intact.

paragraphs.original: What shall be our sport, then?
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, what should we do for fun instead?

paragraphs.original: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go find that hussy, Fortune, and and mock her till she starts distributing her gifts more equally.

paragraphs.original: I would we could do so, for her benefits are mightily misplaced, and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake in her gifts to women.
paragraphs.translated: I wish we could do that, because Fortune gives all of her gifts to the wrong people, and she especially gets things wrong where women are concerned.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis true, for those that she makes fair she scarce makes honest, and those that she makes honest she makes very ill- favoredly.
paragraphs.translated: It's true: the women she makes beautiful she also makes slutty, and the women she makes pure and virginal she also makes ugly.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, now thou goest from Fortune's office to Nature's.
Fortune reigns in gifts of the world, not in the lineaments of
Nature.
paragraphs.translated: No, you're getting Fortune and Nature mixed up: Nature determines how we're made, and Fortune decides what happens to us.

paragraphs.original: Enter TOUCHSTONE
paragraphs.translated: TOUCHSTONE enters.

paragraphs.original: No? When Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by Fortune fall into the fire? Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, really? Well, when Nature makes a person beautiful, can't Fortune make her fall into a fire, thereby making her ugly after all? And even though Nature has given us the wit to have this argument, hasn't Fortune sent this fool here to stop us?

paragraphs.original: Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutter-off of Nature's wit.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and now Fortune is playing a nasty trick on Nature: she's breaking up a show of wit between two naturally witty women with the arrival of a natural fool.

paragraphs.original: Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither, but Nature's, who perceiveth our natural wits too dull to reason of such goddesses, and hath sent this natural for our whetstone, for always the dullness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits. How now, wit, whither wander you?
paragraphs.translated:
Well, maybe this is Nature's work after all. Maybe Nature sensed that we're not smart enough to be having this high-flown discussion about goddesses, so she sent us this fool to use as a mental
whetstone. After all, smart peoples' wits are always sharpened by the presence of a fool. What's up, you wit? Where are you wandering off to?
whetstone

paragraphs.original: Mistress, you must come away to your father.
paragraphs.translated: Mistress, you have to go see your father.

paragraphs.original: Were you made the messenger?
paragraphs.translated: Did they make you the messenger?

paragraphs.original: No, by mine honor, but I was bid to come for you.
paragraphs.translated:
No, by my honor, but they told me to come
get you.
get you

paragraphs.original: Where learned you that oath, fool?
paragraphs.translated: Where'd you learn a phrase like, "by my honor," fool?

paragraphs.original: Of a certain knight that swore by his honor they were good pancakes, and swore by his honor the mustard was naught. Now, I'll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
paragraphs.translated: From a certain knight who swore on his honor that the pancakes he was eating were good, and that the mustard on top of them - he swore on his honor - was bad. Now, I'll swear to the opposite - that the pancakes were rotten, and the mustard was fine - but even so, the knight wasn't lying.

paragraphs.original: How prove you that in the great heap of your knowledge?
paragraphs.translated: And how, out of your great heap of knowledge, will you manage to prove that?

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, please; unleash your wisdom.

paragraphs.original: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.
paragraphs.translated: Watch me: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.

paragraphs.original: By our beards (if we had them), thou art.
paragraphs.translated: By our beards (if we had them), you are a knave.

paragraphs.original: By my knavery (if I had it), then I were. But if you swear by that that is not, you are not forsworn. No more was this knight swearing by his honor, for he never had any; or if he had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancakes or that mustard.
paragraphs.translated: And I swear by my wickedness (if I had any) that I am a knave. But you can't swear by what you don't have - and this knight had no honor, or if he did, he swore it off before he ever saw those pancakes and that mustard.

paragraphs.original: Prithee, who is 't that thou mean'st?
paragraphs.translated: Tell me, who is this knight?

paragraphs.original: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.
paragraphs.translated: A man old Frederick, your father, loves.

paragraphs.original: My father's love is enough to honor him. Enough. Speak no more of him; you'll be whipped for taxation one of these days.
paragraphs.translated: If he has my father's love, then that's enough honor for me. Enough of this. No more talk about my father; you'll be whipped for slander one of these days.

paragraphs.original: The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise men do foolishly.
paragraphs.translated: It's a pity that fools aren't allowed to speak wisely about the foolish things that wise men do.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, thou sayest true. For, since the little wit that fools have was silenced, the little foolery that wise men have makes a great show. Here comes Monsieur Le Beau.
paragraphs.translated:
Honestly, you're speaking the truth - ever since the fools were
silenced, the foolishness of wise men has become all the more apparent. Here comes Monsieur Le Beau.
silenced

paragraphs.original: Enter LE BEAU
paragraphs.translated: LE BEAU enters.

paragraphs.original: With his mouth full of news.
paragraphs.translated: With his mouth full of news.

paragraphs.original: Which he will put on us as pigeons feed their young.
paragraphs.translated: Which he'll shove down our throats the way pigeons feed their young.

paragraphs.original: Then shall we be news-crammed.
paragraphs.translated: Then we'll be stuffed with news.

paragraphs.original:
All the better. We shall be the more marketable. - Bonjour,
Monsieur Le Beau. What's the news?
paragraphs.translated:
Well that's good. If we're
fattened up, we'll be worth more.
fattened



Hello, Monsieur Le Beau. What's the news?

paragraphs.original: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.
paragraphs.translated: Fair princess, you've missed some good sport.

paragraphs.original: Sport? Of what color?
paragraphs.translated:
Sport? Of what
color?
color

paragraphs.original: What color, madam? How shall I answer you?
paragraphs.translated: What color, madam? I don't understand - how should I answer that?

paragraphs.original: As wit and fortune will.
paragraphs.translated: However your wit and luck allow.

paragraphs.original: Or as the Destinies decrees.
paragraphs.translated: Or however the Destinies say you should.

paragraphs.original: Well said. That was laid on with a trowel.
paragraphs.translated:
Nicely done; you laid that on thick.
that

paragraphs.original: Nay, if I keep not my rank -
paragraphs.translated: Well, if I don't keep up my rank -

paragraphs.original: Thou losest thy old smell.
paragraphs.translated:
- you'll lose your
smell.
smell

paragraphs.original: You amaze me, ladies. I would have told you of good wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.
paragraphs.translated: You're confusing me, ladies. I was going to tell you all about a good wrestling match that's going on, which you're missing.

paragraphs.original: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.
paragraphs.translated: Tell us about this wrestling.

paragraphs.original: I will tell you the beginning, and if it please your Ladyships, you may see the end, for the best is yet to do, and here, where you are, they are coming to perform it.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you about the beginning, and if you find that interesting you can see the end. The best is yet to come, and they're going to perform it right here.

paragraphs.original: Well, the beginning that is dead and buried.
paragraphs.translated: Well, we've missed the beginning; it's dead and buried.

paragraphs.original: There comes an old man and his three sons -
paragraphs.translated: There comes an old man with his three sons -

paragraphs.original: I could match this beginning with an old tale.
paragraphs.translated: It sounds like the beginning of an old folktale.

paragraphs.original: Three proper young men of excellent growth and presence.
paragraphs.translated: Three proper young men, all good looking and with great presence -

paragraphs.original: With bills on their necks: "Be it known unto all men by these presents."
paragraphs.translated:
Right, and they wore proclamations around their necks, saying, "Be it known to all men by these
presents - "
presents

paragraphs.original: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the duke's wrestler, which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him. So he served the second, and so the third. Yonder they lie, the poor old man their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping.
paragraphs.translated: The eldest of the three brothers wrestled with Charles, the duke's wrestler. Immediately, Charles threw the brother, breaking three of his ribs; it's not likely he will survive. Charles did the same to the second brother, and the third. They're lying over there, and the poor old man, their father, weeps so piteously over them that the whole audience has joined him in grieving.

paragraphs.original: Alas!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, dear!

paragraphs.original: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have lost?
paragraphs.translated: But tell me, monsieur - what sport are the ladies missing?

paragraphs.original: Why, this that I speak of.
paragraphs.translated: Why, the one I just told you about.

paragraphs.original: Thus men may grow wiser every day. It is the first time that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies.
paragraphs.translated: Men must be getting wiser every day; that's the first time I've heard that rib-breaking was appropriate entertainment for ladies.

paragraphs.original: Or I, I promise thee.
paragraphs.translated: Me too, I swear.

paragraphs.original: But is there any else longs to see this broken music in his sides? Is there yet another dotes upon rib-breaking? Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?
paragraphs.translated: Doesn't anyone else want to see this, and hear breath wheezing out from broken ribs? Does anyone else love rib breaking? Shall we go watch this wrestling, cousin?

paragraphs.original: You must if you stay here, for here is the place appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to perform it.
paragraphs.translated: You're going to have to, if you stay here. This is the place they're scheduled to wrestle, and they're ready to go.

paragraphs.original: Yonder sure they are coming. Let us now stay and see it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I see them coming. Let's stay and watch.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. DUKE FREDERICK, lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and attendants enter.

paragraphs.original: Come on. Since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.
paragraphs.translated: Come on. Since the youth won't be reasoned with, he'll have to suffer for his stubbornness.

paragraphs.original: Is yonder the man?
paragraphs.translated: Is that the man?

paragraphs.original: Even he, madam.
paragraphs.translated: That's him, madam.

paragraphs.original: Alas, he is too young. Yet he looks successfully.
paragraphs.translated: Alas, he is too young. Yet he seems capable.

paragraphs.original: How now, daughter and cousin? Are you crept hither to see the wrestling?
paragraphs.translated: What's up, daughter and niece? Have you snuck over here to watch the wrestling?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord, if you give us permission.

paragraphs.original: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man. In pity of the challenger's youth, I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated. Speak to him, ladies; see if you can move him.
paragraphs.translated: You won't enjoy it much, I can tell you, the odds are so against this young man. Because he's so young, I've tried to discourage him, but he won't listen. Talk to him, ladies. See if you can persuade him.

paragraphs.original: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.
paragraphs.translated: Call him over here, good Monsieur Le Beau.

paragraphs.original: Do so. I'll not be by.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead. I'll make myself scarce.

paragraphs.original: He steps aside.
paragraphs.translated: He steps aside.

paragraphs.original: Monsieur the challenger, the Princess calls for you.
paragraphs.translated: Mister Challenger, the princess wants to speak to you.

paragraphs.original: I attend them with all respect and duty.
paragraphs.translated: I'll wait on them with all respect and duty.

paragraphs.original: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?
paragraphs.translated: Young man, have you challenged Charles the Wrestler?

paragraphs.original: No, fair princess. He is the general challenger. I come but in as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.
paragraphs.translated: No, lovely princess. He is the general challenger. I have only come in - like the others have - to try to fight him with the strength of my youth.

paragraphs.original: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years. You have seen cruel proof of this man's strength. If you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal enterprise. We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.
paragraphs.translated: Young gentleman, you are too bold for your age. You have seen the cruel proof of this man's strength. If you took a good look at yourself, or if you thought about this more carefully, your fear would teach you to act more cautiously. We beg you, for your own sake, to respect your safety and give up.

paragraphs.original: Do, young sir. Your reputation shall not therefore be misprized. We will make it our suit to the duke that the wrestling might not go forward.
paragraphs.translated: Please, young sir. We'll make sure your reputation isn't hurt; we'll take it upon ourselves to argue with the duke that the wrestling match should be called off.

paragraphs.original: I beseech you, punish me not with your hard thoughts, wherein I confess me much guilty to deny so fair and excellent ladies anything. But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial, wherein, if I be foiled, there is but one shamed that was never gracious; if killed, but one dead that was willing to be so. I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing. Only in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.
paragraphs.translated: I beg you not to think poorly of me - though I suppose anyone who could deny anything to such beautiful women deserves to be scorned. But please, send me good thoughts in this match. If I'm beaten, the shame is all mine, and I wasn't in anyone's good graces to begin with. If I'm killed, it will only be the death of a man who was willing to be dead. I won't wrong any of my friends, because I don't have any to mourn for me, and I won't have wronged the world, because I don't have anything in the world. In this world, I'm only taking up space. If I leave, maybe someone more worthy will fill it.

paragraphs.original: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.
paragraphs.translated: I wish I could give you the little strength that I have.

paragraphs.original: And mine, to eke out hers.
paragraphs.translated: Mine too, to join hers.

paragraphs.original: Fare you well. Pray heaven I be deceived in you.
paragraphs.translated: Good luck. I hope to God I'm wrong about your chances.

paragraphs.original: Your heart's desires be with you.
paragraphs.translated: I hope you get what you desire!

paragraphs.original: Come, where is this young gallant that is so desirous to lie with his mother earth?
paragraphs.translated:
Come on, where's the young
show-off who's so eager to lie with mother earth?
show-off

paragraphs.original: Ready, sir; but his will hath in it a more modest working.
paragraphs.translated: Ready, sir, but I have more modest ambitions.

paragraphs.original: You shall try but one fall.
paragraphs.translated: You get only one round.

paragraphs.original: No, I warrant your Grace you shall not entreat him to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'm sure your Grace won't be able to persuade him to try a second round, even though you couldn't dissuade him from trying the first.

paragraphs.original: You mean to mock me after, you should not have mocked me before. But come your ways.
paragraphs.translated:
You should mock me after you've beaten me, not before. Come on.
after

paragraphs.original: Now Hercules be thy speed, young man!
paragraphs.translated:
Hercules give you speed, young man!
Hercules

paragraphs.original: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the leg.
paragraphs.translated: I wish I were invisible, so I could grab that strong fellow by the leg.

paragraphs.original: They wrestle
paragraphs.translated: They wrestle.

paragraphs.original: O excellent young man!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what an excellent young man!

paragraphs.original: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who should down.
paragraphs.translated: If I could shoot lightning bolts from my eyes, I can tell you who'd be on the ground.

paragraphs.original: CHARLES is thrown Shout
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO throws Charles. The crowd shouts.

paragraphs.original: No more, no more.
paragraphs.translated: No more, no more.

paragraphs.original: Yes, I beseech your Grace. I am not yet well breathed.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come on, your Grace - I'm barely out of breath.

paragraphs.original: How dost thou, Charles?
paragraphs.translated: How are you doing, Charles?

paragraphs.original: He cannot speak, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: He can't speak, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Bear him away. What is thy name, young man?
paragraphs.translated: Carry him away. What is your name, young man?

paragraphs.original:
Orlando, my liege, the youngest son of Sir Rowland de
Boys.
paragraphs.translated: Orlando, my lord, the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

paragraphs.original:
I would thou hadst been son to some man else.
The world esteemed thy father honorable,
But I did find him still mine enemy.
Thou shouldst have better pleased me with this deed
Hadst thou descended from another house.
But fare thee well. Thou art a gallant youth.
I would thou hadst told me of another father.
paragraphs.translated: I wish you were someone else's son. The whole world thought your father was an honorable man, but he was always my enemy. Your victory would have pleased me more if you'd been someone else's son. But good luck; you are a brave young man. I wish you had told me you had a different father.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK, train, and LE BEAU
paragraphs.translated: DUKE FREDERICK, his train, and LE BEAU exit.

paragraphs.original: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?
paragraphs.translated: If I were my father, cousin, would I do this?

paragraphs.original:
I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son,
His youngest son, and would not change that calling
To be adopted heir to Frederick.
paragraphs.translated: I'm proud to be Sir Rowland's son - his youngest son - and I would never change that, not even to be Frederick's adopted heir.

paragraphs.original:
My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul,
And all the world was of my father's mind.
Had I before known this young man his son,
I should have given him tears unto entreaties
Ere he should thus have ventured.
paragraphs.translated: My father loved Sir Rowland as much as he loved his own soul, and the rest of the world shared my father's opinion. If I had known this young man was his son, I would have tried harder to convince him not to fight.

paragraphs.original:
Gentle cousin,
Let us go thank him and encourage him.
My father's rough and envious disposition
Sticks me at heart. - Sir, you have well deserved.
If you do keep your promises in love
But justly, as you have exceeded all promise,
Your mistress shall be happy.

Gentleman,
(giving him a chain from her neck)
(giving him a chain from her neck)
Wear this for me - one out of suits with fortune
That could give more but that her hand lacks means.
 - Shall we go, coz?
paragraphs.translated:
(giving him a chain from her neck) Gentleman, wear this for me. I'm a woman who's down on her luck, and I'd give more if I could. Shall we go, cousin?
(giving him a chain from her neck)

paragraphs.original: Ay. - Fare you well, fair gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: Yes. Good luck, fair gentleman.

paragraphs.original:
Can I not say "I thank you"? My better parts
Are all thrown down, and that which here stands up
Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Can't I even say "thank you"? I left my brain back on the wrestling field. What's left of me is a dummy, just a lifeless block.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
He calls us back. My pride fell with my fortunes.
I'll ask him what he would. - Did you call, sir?
Sir, you have wrestled well and overthrown
More than your enemies.
paragraphs.translated:
He's calling us back. My
pride fell when my fortunes did; I'll ask him what he wants. - Did you call us, sir? Sir, you wrestled well and conquered more than just your enemies.
pride

paragraphs.original: Will you go, coz?
paragraphs.translated: Will you come on, cousin?

paragraphs.original: Have with you. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: I'm coming. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND and CELIA exit.

paragraphs.original:
What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.
O poor Orlando! Thou art overthrown.
Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
paragraphs.translated: What is this passion that ties up my tongue? I can't speak to her, even though she asked me to. Oh, poor Orlando, you've been overthrown! Either Charles or some prettier thing has mastered you.

paragraphs.original: Enter LE BEAU
paragraphs.translated: LE BEAU enters.

paragraphs.original:
Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you
To leave this place. Albeit you have deserved
High commendation, true applause, and love,
Yet such is now the duke's condition
That he misconsters all that you have done.
The duke is humorous. What he is indeed
More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.
paragraphs.translated: Good sir, as a friend, I advise you to leave this place. Although you deserve praise, applause, and love, right now the duke misconstrues everything you've done. The duke is temperamental. I'm sure you can imagine what I mean without my having to spell it out.

paragraphs.original:
I thank you, sir, and pray you tell me this:
Which of the two was daughter of the duke
That here was at the wrestling?
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, sir. Now please tell me this: which of the two ladies who were at the wrestling match is the duke's daughter?

paragraphs.original:
Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners,
But yet indeed the smaller is his daughter
The other is daughter to the banished duke,
And here detained by her usurping uncle
To keep his daughter company, whose loves
Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters.
But I can tell you that of late this duke
Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece,
Grounded upon no other argument
But that the people praise her for her virtues
And pity her for her good father's sake;
And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady
Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well.
Hereafter, in a better world than this,
I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.
paragraphs.translated: Neither one is his daughter, to judge from their good manners. But really, the smaller one is his daughter. The other is the daughter of the banished duke. Duke Frederick keeps her for his daughter's sake; the love between the two of them is stronger than the bond between sisters. But I will tell you that lately the duke has been displeased with his niece, and for no other reason than that people praise her virtues and pity her for her father's sake. I swear, one day the duke's malice toward Rosalind will suddenly erupt. Goodbye, sir. Later, in a better world than this, I'd love to get to know you.

paragraphs.original: I rest much bounden to you. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: I'm indebted to you. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit LE BEAU
paragraphs.translated: LE BEAU exits.

paragraphs.original:
Thus must I from the smoke into the smother,
From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother.
But heavenly Rosalind!
paragraphs.translated: Out of the frying pan and into the fire - from a tyrant duke to a tyrant brother! But, oh, heavenly Rosalind!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND
paragraphs.translated: CELIA and ROSALIND enter.

paragraphs.original: Why, cousin! Why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy, not a word?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on, Rosalind? Cupid have mercy! You won't utter a single word?

paragraphs.original: Not one to throw at a dog.
paragraphs.translated: I don't even have one to throw at a dog.

paragraphs.original:
No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs.
Throw some of them at me. Come, lame me with reasons.
paragraphs.translated: No, your words are too precious to be wasted on dogs. Throw some of your words at me. Come on, throw your words at me like you would throw stones at a dog.

paragraphs.original: Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any.
paragraphs.translated: Then there would be two cousins lying sick in bed: one hurt by reasons and the other gone crazy without any.

paragraphs.original: But is all this for your father?
paragraphs.translated: Is all of this about your father?

paragraphs.original: No, some of it is for my child's father. Oh, how full of briers is this working-day world!
paragraphs.translated:
No, some of it is about my child's father. Oh, this
working-day world is full of thorns!
working-day

paragraphs.original: They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in holiday foolery. If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.
paragraphs.translated: They're only burrs, cousin, thrown at you because you took a holiday from conventional behavior. If we walk on the well-worn paths, they won't get caught in our petticoats.

paragraphs.original: I could shake them off my coat. These burs are in my heart.
paragraphs.translated: Those burrs I could shake off my clothing, but these are in my heart.

paragraphs.original: Hem them away.
paragraphs.translated: Cough them up.

paragraphs.original: I would try, if I could cry "hem" and have him.
paragraphs.translated: I'd try it, if I could cry "hem" and have him.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, take control of your feelings.

paragraphs.original: Oh, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself.
paragraphs.translated: But they're siding with a better wrestler than myself.

paragraphs.original: Oh, a good wish upon you. You will try in time, in despite of a fall. But turning these jests out of service, let us talk in good earnest. Is it possible on such a sudden you should fall into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's youngest son?
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, that's a good wish! You'll fight with him eventually, and
fall. But let's put these jokes aside for a moment, and speak earnestly. Is it possible that you could have fallen in love with Orlando, Sir Rowland's youngest son, this suddenly?
fall

paragraphs.original: The duke my father loved his father dearly.
paragraphs.translated: The duke, my father, loved his father very much.

paragraphs.original: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly? By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly. Yet I hate not Orlando.
paragraphs.translated: Does that necessarily mean you should love his son? By that kind of logic, I should hate Orlando, since my father hates his father. But I don't hate Orlando.

paragraphs.original: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.
paragraphs.translated: No, please don't hate him - for my sake.

paragraphs.original: Why should I not? Doth he not deserve well?
paragraphs.translated: Why shouldn't I? Doesn't he deserve it?

paragraphs.original:
Let me love him for that, and do you love him because I do.
Look, here comes the duke.
paragraphs.translated: Let me love him because he deserves it, and you can love him because I do. Look, here comes the duke.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE FREDERICK with lords
paragraphs.translated: DUKE FREDERICK enters, with lords

paragraphs.original: With his eyes full of anger.
paragraphs.translated: He looks angry.

paragraphs.original:
Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste,
And get you from our court.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, hurry as fast as you can get out of my court.

paragraphs.original: Me, uncle?
paragraphs.translated: Me, uncle?

paragraphs.original:
You, cousin.
Within these ten days if that thou beest found
So near our public court as twenty miles,
Thou diest for it.
paragraphs.translated: You, niece. In ten days time, if you're found within twenty miles of the court, you'll die for it.

paragraphs.original:
I do beseech your Grace,
Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me.
If with myself I hold intelligence
Or have acquaintance with mine own desires,
If that I do not dream or be not frantic - 
As I do trust I am not - then, dear uncle,
Never so much as in a thought unborn
Did I offend your Highness.
paragraphs.translated: Please, your Grace, tell me what crime I have committed. If I know my own thoughts and desires, and I'm not dreaming or crazy - which I'm sure I'm not - then, dear uncle, I've never had so much as a half-formed thought that would have offended you.

paragraphs.original:
Thus do all traitors.
If their purgation did consist in words,
They are as innocent as grace itself.
Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.
paragraphs.translated: All traitors protest like this. If they could purge their guilt simply by saying that they were innocent, they'd all be as innocent as God Himself. I don't trust you. Enough said.

paragraphs.original:
Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor.
Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.
paragraphs.translated: But your mistrust alone can't make me a traitor - on what basis do you suspect me?

paragraphs.original: Thou art thy father's daughter. There's enough.
paragraphs.translated: You are your father's daughter. That's enough.

paragraphs.original:
So was I when your Highness took his dukedom.
So was I when your Highness banished him.
Treason is not inherited, my lord,
Or if we did derive it from our friends,
What's that to me? My father was no traitor.
Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much
To think my poverty is treacherous.
paragraphs.translated: I was his daughter when your Highness took my father's dukedom. I was his daughter when you banished him. Treason is not inherited, my lord. But even if we did inherit it from our family, what does that have to do with me? My father wasn't a traitor. So, please, my lord, don't assume that I'm treacherous just because I'm poor, with no titles to my name.

paragraphs.original: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
paragraphs.translated: Dear master, listen to me.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, Celia, we stayed her for your sake.
Else had she with her father ranged along.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Celia, we kept her here for your sake. Otherwise, she would have been banished with her father.

paragraphs.original:
I did not then entreat to have her stay.
It was your pleasure and your own remorse.
I was too young that time to value her,
But now I know her. If she be a traitor,
Why so am I. We still have slept together,
Rose at an instant, learned, played, eat together,
And, wheresoe'er we went, like Juno's swans
Still we went coupled and inseparable.
paragraphs.translated: At that time, I didn't beg you to keep her here; you wanted her here, and you felt guilty. I was too young at the time to appreciate her value, but now I know her. If she's a traitor, why then, so am I. We have always slept together, woken up together, learned, played, and eaten together. Wherever we went, we went together and inseparable.

paragraphs.original:
She is too subtle for thee, and her smoothness,
Her very silence and her patience
Speak to the people, and they pity her.
Thou art a fool. She robs thee of thy name,
And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
When she is gone. Then open not thy lips.
Firm and irrevocable is my doom
Which I have passed upon her. She is banished.
paragraphs.translated: She's too devious for you. Her smoothness, her silence, and her patient suffering appeal to the people, and they pity her. You're a fool. She's robbing you of the attention you deserve. You will seem even brighter and more virtuous when she's out of the picture. So be quiet. The sentence I've passed down on her is firm and unshakeable. She is banished.

paragraphs.original:
Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege.
I cannot live out of her company.
paragraphs.translated: Then lay that sentence on me too, my lord. I cannot live without her.

paragraphs.original:
You are a fool. - You, niece, provide yourself.
If you outstay the time, upon mine honor
And in the greatness of my word, you die.
paragraphs.translated: You are a fool. - You, niece, prepare to leave. On my honor and by my word, if you outstay the ten days, you will die.

paragraphs.original: DUKE FREDERICK and lords exit.
paragraphs.translated: Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK and lords

paragraphs.original:
O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?
Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.
I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my poor Rosalind, where will you go? Do you want to exchange fathers? I'll give you mine. I insist, don't be more distressed than I am.

paragraphs.original: I have more cause.
paragraphs.translated: I have more reason to be distressed.

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast not, cousin.
Prithee, be cheerful. Know'st thou not the duke
Hath banished me, his daughter?
paragraphs.translated: No you haven't, cousin. Please, be cheerful. Don't you realize the duke has also banished me, his daughter?

paragraphs.original: That he hath not.
paragraphs.translated: No, he hasn't.

paragraphs.original:
No, hath not? Rosalind lacks then the love
Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one.
Shall we be sundered? Shall we part, sweet girl?
No, let my father seek another heir.
Therefore devise with me how we may fly,
Whither to go, and what to bear with us,
And do not seek to take your change upon you,
To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out.
For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale,
Say what thou canst, I'll go along with thee.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, he hasn't? Well, then, you don't have the affection that would teach you that you and I are one. Will we be separated? Should we part, sweet girl? No. Let my father find another heir. So, help me plan how we'll escape, where we'll go, and what we'll take with us. Don't even try to take this all upon yourself, bearing your grief alone and leaving me out. I swear by the heavens, which have grown pale in sympathy with us, I'm going with you, whatever you say.

paragraphs.original: Why, whither shall we go?
paragraphs.translated: But where will we go?

paragraphs.original: To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden.
paragraphs.translated: To the Forest of Arden, to find your father.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, what danger will it be to us,
Maids as we are, to travel forth so far?
Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
paragraphs.translated: But what danger we'll put ourselves in, two young, innocent women traveling so far! Fresh beauty attracts thugs and thieves even more than money.

paragraphs.original:
I'll put myself in poor and mean attire
And with a kind of umber smirch my face.
The like do you. So shall we pass along
And never stir assailants.
paragraphs.translated: I'll put on some poor and ragged clothes and smudge my face with dirt. You do the same, and we'll be able to travel without attracting any attackers' attention.

paragraphs.original:
Were it not better,
Because that I am more than common tall,
That I did suit me all points like a man?
A gallant curtal-axe upon my thigh,
A boar-spear in my hand, and in my heart
Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will,
We'll have a swashing and a martial outside - 
As many other mannish cowards have
That do outface it with their semblances.
paragraphs.translated:
Wouldn't it be better - since I'm unusually tall for a woman - to dress myself like a man?
I'll wear a big sword in my belt, carry a boar-spear in my hand, and hide all my womanish fear in my heart. We'll maintain a swaggering, warrior look, like so many cowardly men, whose manner has nothing to do with what they're feeling.

paragraphs.original: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?
paragraphs.translated: What should I call you when you're a man?

paragraphs.original:
I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page,
And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
But what will you be called?
paragraphs.translated:
I'll take no lesser name than that of
Jove's own servant. So call me Ganymede. And what will you be called?
Jove's

paragraphs.original:
Something that hath a reference to my state:
No longer Celia, but Aliena.
paragraphs.translated: Something that refers to my current state. Instead of Celia, call me Aliena.

paragraphs.original:
But, cousin, what if we assayed to steal
The clownish fool out of your father's court?
Would he not be a comfort to our travel?
paragraphs.translated: Cousin, what if we brought that clownish fool of your father's court, Touchstone? Wouldn't he be a comfort to us in our travels?

paragraphs.original:
He'll go along o'er the wide world with me.
Leave me alone to woo him. Let's away
And get our jewels and our wealth together,
Devise the fittest time and safest way
To hide us from pursuit that will be made
After my flight. Now go we in content
To liberty, and not to banishment.
paragraphs.translated: He'd walk the whole wide world with me. Leave me alone to go convince him. Let's go gather our jewels and money. We'll figure out the best time and safest route to avoid being found out by my father's guards, whom he'll send out as soon as he discovers I've gone. Now, we go contentedly to freedom - not banishment.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS, like foresters
paragraphs.translated: DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS enter, dressed like foresters.

paragraphs.original:
Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,
Hath not old custom made this life more sweet
Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods
More free from peril than the envious court?
Here feel we not the penalty of Adam,
The seasons' difference, as the icy fang
And churlish chiding of the winter's wind,
Which, when it bites and blows upon my body,
Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say,
"This is no flattery. These are counselors
That feelingly persuade me what I am."
Sweet are the uses of adversity,
Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,
Wears yet a precious jewel in his head.
And this our life, exempt from public haunt,
Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks,
Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
paragraphs.translated:
Now, my companions and brothers in exile, hasn't experience made this simple life sweeter than a life of glittery pomp and circumstance? Aren't these woods less perilous than the court, with all its jealousies and intrigues? Out here we feel the changing of the seasons, but we're not bothered by it. When the icy fangs of the brutal, scolding wind bite and blow on my body, even though I'm shivering with cold, I can appreciate the weather's honesty. I smile and think, "Thank goodness the wind doesn't flatter me: it's like a councilor who makes me feel what I'm really made of." Adversity can have its benefits - like the ugly, poisonous
toad that wears a precious jewel in its forehead. In this life, far away from the civilized world, we can hear the language of the trees, read the books of the running streams, hear sermons in the stones, and discover the good in every single thing.
toad

paragraphs.original:
I would not change it. Happy is your Grace,
That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't change my situation for anything. You're lucky, my lord, to be able to see the peace and sweetness even in what bad luck has brought you.

paragraphs.original:
Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,
Being native burghers of this desert city,
Should in their own confines with forkèd heads
Have their round haunches gored.
paragraphs.translated: Come, shall we hunt some deer for dinner? It bothers me, though, that these poor spotted innocents, who, after all, are this deserted city's native citizens, should be gouged with arrows.

paragraphs.original:
Indeed, my lord,
The melancholy Jaques grieves at that,
And in that kind swears you do more usurp
Than doth your brother that hath banished you.
Today my Lord of Amiens and myself
Did steal behind him as he lay along
Under an oak, whose antique root peeps out
Upon the brook that brawls along this wood,
To the which place a poor sequestered stag
That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt
Did come to languish. And indeed, my lord,
The wretched animal heaved forth such groans
That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
Almost to bursting, and the big round tears
Coursed one another down his innocent nose
In piteous chase. And thus the hairy fool,
Much markèd of the melancholy Jaques,
Stood on th' extremest verge of the swift brook,
Augmenting it with tears.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, my lord, the gloomy Jaques grieves over these deaths. He swears that when you kill the deer, you're a worse usurper than your brother was for banishing you. Today, Lord Amiens and I followed Jaques. We saw him lie down along a brook under an oak tree whose ancient roots peeked out from the earth. A poor, lonely stag who had been hurt by a hunter's arrow came to rest there, where he heaved such heavy groans that the effort seemed to stretch his hide to bursting. Big, round tears ran piteously down the animal's innocent nose. The hairy fool, watched closely by sad Jaques, stood on the very edge of the brook, adding his own tears to the streaming water.

paragraphs.original:
But what said Jaques?
Did he not moralize this spectacle?
paragraphs.translated: And what did Jaques say? Didn't he take the opportunity to draw a moral from the scene?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, yes, into a thousand similes.
First, for his weeping into the needless stream:
"Poor deer," quoth he, "thou mak'st a testament
As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more
To that which had too much." Then, being there alone,
Left and abandoned of his velvet friend,
"'Tis right," quoth he. "Thus misery doth part
The flux of company." Anon a careless herd,
Full of the pasture, jumps along by him
And never stays to greet him. "Ay," quoth Jaques,
"Sweep on, you fat and greasy citizens.
'Tis just the fashion. Wherefore do you look
Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?"
Thus most invectively he pierceth through
The body of the country, city, court,
Yea, and of this our life, swearing that we
Are mere usurpers, tyrants, and what's worse,
To fright the animals and to kill them up
In their assigned and native dwelling place.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes, he created a thousand comparisons. First, he spoke of the deer's needless addition to the stream's water supply. "Poor deer," he said, "you're just like a human: you add more to what already has too much." Then, about the deer's being alone, abandoned by his velvety companions: "It's appropriate," he said, "that a miserable creature should excuse itself from company." Just then, a carefree herd of deer, having just eaten their fill of pasture grass, bounded along without stopping to greet their wounded brother. "Sure," said Jaques, "hurry on, you fat and greasy citizens. Why stop and notice this poor, broken, bankrupt creature here?" In this way, he most insightfully pierced to the heart of the country, the city, the court, and even our lives out here in the forest, swearing that we are mere usurpers and tyrants, frightening and killing animals in their own homes.

paragraphs.original: And did you leave him in this contemplation?
paragraphs.translated: And did you leave him like this?

paragraphs.original:
We did, my lord, weeping and commenting
Upon the sobbing deer.
paragraphs.translated: We did, my lord, weeping and carrying on about the sobbing deer.

paragraphs.original:
Show me the place.
I love to cope him in these sullen fits,
For then he's full of matter.
paragraphs.translated: Take me to him. I love to argue with him when he's having one of these fits, because then he always has a lot to say.

paragraphs.original: I'll bring you to him straight.
paragraphs.translated: I'll bring you to him right away.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS
paragraphs.translated: DUKE FREDERICK enters, with LORDS

paragraphs.original:
Can it be possible that no man saw them?
It cannot be. Some villains of my court
Are of consent and sufferance in this.
paragraphs.translated: Can it be possible that no one saw them leave? It cannot be. Some villains in my court must have known about this and let it happen.

paragraphs.original:
I cannot hear of any that did see her.
The ladies, her attendants of her chamber
Saw her abed, and in the morning early
They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.
paragraphs.translated: I can't find anyone who saw her leave. Her ladies-in-waiting saw her go to bed, and early this morning the bed was empty.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, the roinish clown, at whom so oft
Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
Hisperia, the Princess' gentlewoman,
Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
Your daughter and her cousin much commend
The parts and graces of the wrestler
That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles,
And she believes wherever they are gone
That youth is surely in their company.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, that dirty clown whom you laughed at so often is also missing. Hisperia, the princess's gentlewoman, confesses that she overheard your daughter and her cousin praising the good looks and skills of the wrestler who recently beat the muscular Charles. Hisperia believes that, wherever they have gone, that young man is likely with them.

paragraphs.original:
Send to his brother. Fetch that gallant hither.
If he be absent, bring his brother to me.
I'll make him find him. Do this suddenly,
And let not search and inquisition quail
To bring again these foolish runaways.
paragraphs.translated: Send a message to his brother. Bring that swinger Orlando here. If he's not around, bring his brother Oliver to me. I'll make Oliver find him. Do this immediately, and don't stop searching and interrogating until you've brought home these foolish runaways.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM, meeting
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and ADAM enter from opposite sides of the stage.

paragraphs.original: Who's there?
paragraphs.translated: Who's there?

paragraphs.original:
What, my young master, O my gentle master,
O my sweet master, O you memory
Of old Sir Rowland! Why, what make you here?
Why are you virtuous? Why do people love you?
And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant?
Why would you be so fond to overcome
The bonny prizer of the humorous duke?
Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
Know you not, master, to some kind of men
Their graces serve them but as enemies?
No more do yours. Your virtues, gentle master,
Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.
Oh, what a world is this when what is comely
Envenoms him that bears it!
paragraphs.translated: My young master! Oh, my gentle master! My sweet master! Oh, you living memory of old Sir Rowland! What are you doing here? Why are you so strong and good? Why do people love you? And why are you noble, strong, and brave? Why would you be so foolish as to beat the moody duke's favorite champion? Your praise has beaten you home. Don't you know, master, that some men's best qualities do them in? Yours are like that - complete and utter traitors to you. Oh, what a world this is, when even what is beautiful in a man poisons him!

paragraphs.original: Why, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
O unhappy youth,
Come not within these doors. Within this roof
The enemy of all your graces lives.
Your brother - no, no brother - yet the son - 
Yet not the son, I will not call him son - 
Of him I was about to call his father
Hath heard your praises, and this night he means
To burn the lodging where you use to lie,
And you within it. If he fail of that,
He will have other means to cut you off.
I overheard him and his practices.
This is no place, this house is but a butchery.
Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, unlucky boy! Don't walk through these doors. In this house lives a man who despises all that is good in you. Oliver, your brother - no, not your brother; and yet he's the son - but no, I won't call him the son - of that great man I was about to call his father, has heard about how well you did in the wrestling match, and tonight he's planning on burning your house down, with you in it. And if he fails at that, he will find other ways to kill you. I overheard him and his plans. This is no place for you; this home is now a slaughterhouse. Hate it, fear it, do not come inside.

paragraphs.original: Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?
paragraphs.translated: Then where would you have me go, Adam?

paragraphs.original: No matter whither, so you come not here.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't matter where, so long as it's not here.

paragraphs.original:
What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food,
Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce
A thievish living on the common road?
This I must do, or know not what to do.
Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
I rather will subject me to the malice
Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
paragraphs.translated: What, would you have me beg for my food? Or become a lowlife, sticking up travelers on the road? This is all that's left for me to do, but I won't do it. I'd rather give myself up to the hatred of a violent brother who refuses to recognize that we are brothers.

paragraphs.original:
But do not so. I have five hundred crowns,
The thrifty hire I saved under your father,
Which I did store to be my foster nurse
When service should in my old limbs lie lame
And unregarded age in corners thrown.
Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
Be comfort to my age. Here is the gold.
All this I give you. Let me be your servant.
Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty,
For in my youth I never did apply
Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood
Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
The means of weakness and debility.
Therefore my age is as a lusty winter,
Frosty but kindly. Let me go with you.
I'll do the service of a younger man
In all your business and necessities.
paragraphs.translated: But don't do that. I have five-hundred gold coins, which I carefully saved when I was working for your late father. I meant to use it for my retirement, to help me when my old body was lame and forgotten in some dark corner. But take the money, and God, who feeds even the raven and looks after even the sparrow, will comfort me in my old age. Here is the gold, I give it all to you. Let me be your servant. I know I may be old, but I'm strong and healthy, because in my youth I never drank nor lived recklessly. Therefore, my old age is like a blustery winter: cold, but kindly. Let me go with you. I'll do everything a younger man could do for you.

paragraphs.original:
O good old man, how well in thee appears
The constant service of the antique world,
When service sweat for duty, not for meed.
Thou art not for the fashion of these times,
Where none will sweat but for promotion,
And having that do choke their service up
Even with the having. It is not so with thee.
But, poor old man, thou prun'st a rotten tree
That cannot so much as a blossom yield
In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry.
But come thy ways. We'll go along together,
And ere we have thy youthful wages spent,
We'll light upon some settled low content.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, good old man, you're a great example of that old work ethic, where people worked because it was their duty, not just for the money. Your approach isn't the fashion these days, when no one works hard except for a promotion, and, as soon as they've got it, they stop working. But in working for me, old man, you are pruning a rotten tree: despite all your pains and efforts, it won't yield a single blossom. Come along, though. We'll go together, and before we've spent all the savings of your youth, we'll find a way to make a living.

paragraphs.original:
Master, go on, and I will follow thee
To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
From seventeen years till now almost fourscore
Here livèd I, but now live here no more.
At seventeen years, many their fortunes seek,
But at fourscore, it is too late a week.
Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
Than to die well, and not my master's debtor.
paragraphs.translated: Go on, master, and I will follow you - with truth and loyalty to my last breath. From the time I was seventeen, over sixty years ago, I have lived in this house, but now I will live here no more. Many men seek their fortune at seventeen; at eighty, it's a bit late. But fortune could not reward me better than to let me die well, without owing my master anything.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND for Ganymede, CELIA for Aliena, and TOUCHSTONE
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND (dressed as Ganymede), CELIA (dressed as Aliena), and TOUCHSTONE enter.

paragraphs.original: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!
paragraphs.translated: Oh Lord, my spirits are tired!

paragraphs.original: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't care about my spirits, if my legs weren't tired.

paragraphs.original: I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's apparel and to cry like a woman, but I must comfort the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose ought to show itself courageous to petticoat. Therefore courage, good Aliena.
paragraphs.translated:
I'd insult my manly wardrobe by weeping like a woman if I didn't have to comfort the weaker vessel here, as the
jacket and hose ought to be brave for the sake of the petticoat. So, have courage, good Aliena.
jacket and hose

paragraphs.original: I pray you bear with me. I cannot go no further.
paragraphs.translated: Please bear with me. I can't go any further.

paragraphs.original: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you. Yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you, for I think you have no money in your purse.
paragraphs.translated:
I'd rather bear with you than
bear you. But if I did carry you, it would be no
cross to bear, because I'm pretty sure you don't have any money.
bear



cross

paragraphs.original: Well, this is the Forest of Arden.
paragraphs.translated: Well, this is the Forest of Arden.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, now am I in Arden, the more fool I. When I was at home
I was in a better place, but travelers must be content.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, now I'm in Arden, and that makes me the bigger fool. When I was at home, I was in a better place. But travelers have to be content.

paragraphs.original: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, be content, good Touchstone.

paragraphs.original: Enter CORIN and SILVIUS
paragraphs.translated: CORIN and SILVIUS enter.

paragraphs.original: Look you who comes here, a young man and an old in solemn talk.
paragraphs.translated: Look who's coming: a young man and an old man, having a serious talk.

paragraphs.original: That is the way to make her scorn you still.
paragraphs.translated: What you're doing is the way to make her scorn you continually.

paragraphs.original: O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Corin, I wish you could understand how much I love her!

paragraphs.original: I partly guess, for I have loved ere now.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sure I can guess. I have been in love too, you know.

paragraphs.original:
No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess,
Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover
As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.
But if thy love were ever like to mine - 
As sure I think did never man love so - 
How many actions most ridiculous
Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?
paragraphs.translated: No Corin, since you're old, you cannot guess - even if you were as dedicated a lover in your youth as there ever was, sighing and mooning all night long. If your love was anything like mine - and I'm sure that no man has loved as I love now - exactly how many ridiculous actions did your fantasizing lead you to?

paragraphs.original: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, a thousand of them, all of which I've forgotten.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, thou didst then ne'er love so heartily.
If thou rememb'rest not the slightest folly
That ever love did make thee run into,
Thou hast not loved.
Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,
Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress's praise,
Thou hast not loved.
Or if thou hast not broke from company
Abruptly, as my passion now makes me,
Thou hast not loved.
O Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!
