paragraphs.translated: Oh, then you never loved as wholeheartedly as me. If you can't remember the stupidest little thing love made you do, you haven't loved. Or if you haven't sat as I do now, boring your listener with all your lover's virtues, then you haven't loved. Or if you haven't broken away from human company, as my feelings now lead me to do, you haven't loved. O Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, poor shepherd, searching of thy wound,
I have by hard adventure found mine own.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, poor shepherd! Listening to you speak of your wounded heart reminds me of my own pain.

paragraphs.original: And I mine. I remember when I was in love I broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a- night to Jane Smile. And I remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow's dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked. And I remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took two cods and, giving her them again, said with weeping tears, "Wear these for my sake." We that are true lovers run into strange capers. But as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.
paragraphs.translated: Me too. I remember when I was in love, I broke my sword on a stone, and told him to take that for coming at night to see Jane Smile. I remember kissing her washing stick and the cow's udders that her pretty, chapped hands had milked. I remember wooing a pea plant in her name, and then taking two pea pods and begging her to wear them "for my sake." Those of us who are really in love will do the strangest things. But everything that lives is mortal, including the foolishness of love.

paragraphs.original: Thou speak'st wiser than thou art ware of.
paragraphs.translated: You speak more wisely than you know.

paragraphs.original: Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break my shins against it.
paragraphs.translated: Nah, I'll never be aware of my own wit, until I break my shins on it.

paragraphs.original:
Jove, Jove, this shepherd's passion
Is much upon my fashion.
paragraphs.translated: By God! This shepherd's condition is like my own.

paragraphs.original: And mine, but it grows something stale with me.
paragraphs.translated: And like mine, but I'm getting a little tired of it.

paragraphs.original: I pray you, one of you question yond man, if he for gold will give us any food. I faint almost to death.
paragraphs.translated: Please, one of you go ask that man over there if we can buy some food off him. I'm faint with hunger.

paragraphs.original:
(to CORIN) Holla, you clown!
(to
paragraphs.translated:
(to CORIN) Hey, clown!
(to

paragraphs.original: Peace, fool. He's not thy kinsman.
paragraphs.translated: Shut up, fool. He's not your relative.

paragraphs.original: Who calls?
paragraphs.translated: Who's calling?

paragraphs.original: Your betters, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Your superiors.

paragraphs.original: Else are they very wretched.
paragraphs.translated: If they weren't my betters, they'd be pretty wretched indeed.

paragraphs.original: Peace, I say.  - Good even to you, friend.
And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening to you, too, noble sir, and to all of you.

paragraphs.original:
I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold
Can in this desert place buy entertainment,
Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.
Here's a young maid with travel much oppressed,
And faints for succor.
paragraphs.translated: Please sir, if love or money can buy anything in this empty place, tell us where we can rest and feed ourselves. We'll pay you for the information. We have a young woman here who is very tired from traveling and faint with hunger.

paragraphs.original:
Fair sir, I pity her
And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,
My fortunes were more able to relieve her.
But I am shepherd to another man
And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.
My master is of churlish disposition
And little recks to find the way to heaven
By doing deeds of hospitality.
Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed
Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now,
By reason of his absence, there is nothing
That you will feed on. But what is, come see,
And in my voice most welcome shall you be.
paragraphs.translated: Dear sir, I pity the lady and wish - more for her sake than my own - that I was more able to help her. But I'm a hired hand: I don't profit from the flocks I tend. My master is a brutish man and doesn't care much if he gets to heaven by deeds of hospitality or not. Besides, his cottage, his flocks, and his grazing rights are on sale now, and since he's not there, there's nothing to eat at our house. But let's see what's on hand. If I have anything to say about it, you will be most welcome there.

paragraphs.original: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?
paragraphs.translated: Who wants to buy the flock and the pasture?

paragraphs.original:
That young swain that you saw here but erewhile,
That little cares for buying anything.
paragraphs.translated: That young man who was just here. But he doesn't really care about buying anything.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, if it stand with honesty,
Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock,
And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.
paragraphs.translated: Please, if you can do it without taking advantage of the young man, buy the cottage, pasture, and flock for us, and we'll pay you for it.

paragraphs.original:
And we will mend thy wages. I like this place,
And willingly could waste my time in it.
paragraphs.translated: And we will raise your wages. I like this place. I could see myself wasting time here.

paragraphs.original:
Assuredly the thing is to be sold.
Go with me. If you like upon report
The soil, the profit, and this kind of life,
I will your very faithful feeder be
And buy it with your gold right suddenly.
paragraphs.translated: The thing is definitely going to be sold. Come with me. If you like what you see of the land, the profit that's possible, and this rustic life, I'll be your faithful servant, and buy the place with your gold right away.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMIENS, JAQUES, and others
paragraphs.translated: AMIENS, JAQUES, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Under the greenwood tree
Under the greenwood tree
Who loves to lie with me
Who loves to lie with me
And turn his merry note
And turn his merry note
Unto the sweet bird's throat,
Unto the sweet bird's throat,
Come hither, come hither, come hither.
Come hither, come hither, come hither.
Here shall he see
Here shall he see
No enemy
No enemy
But winter and rough weather.
But winter and rough weather.
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
Whoever wants to lie with me,
Whoever wants to lie with me,
Under the greenwood tree,
Under the greenwood tree,
And turn his merry song
And turn his merry song
To follow the sweet bird's singing,
To follow the sweet bird's singing,
Come here, come here, come here.
Come here, come here, come here.
Here you will find
Here you will find
No enemy
No enemy
Besides winter and rough weather.
Besides winter and rough weather.

paragraphs.original: More, more, I prithee, more.
paragraphs.translated: More, more, please, more.

paragraphs.original: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.
paragraphs.translated: It's only going to make you sad, Monsieur Jaques.

paragraphs.original: I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck melancholy out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs. More, I prithee, more.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad about that. More, please, more. I can suck sadness out of a song the way a weasel sucks eggs. More, please, more.

paragraphs.original: My voice is ragged. I know I cannot please you.
paragraphs.translated: My voice is ragged. I know I won't please you.

paragraphs.original:
I do not desire you to please me. I do desire you to sing.
Come, more, another stanzo. Call you 'em "stanzos"?
paragraphs.translated: I don't want you to please me, I want you to sing. Come on, another stanza - is that what you call 'em, "stanzas"?

paragraphs.original: What you will, Monsieur Jaques.
paragraphs.translated: Call them whatever you want, Monsieur Jaques.

paragraphs.original: Nay, I care not for their names. They owe me nothing. Will you sing?
paragraphs.translated:
Nah, I don't care what their
names are; they owe me nothing. Will you sing?
names

paragraphs.original: More at your request than to please myself.
paragraphs.translated: Okay, but only because you want me to.

paragraphs.original: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I'll thank you. But that they call "compliment" is like th' encounter of two dog- apes. And when a man thanks me heartily, methinks I have given him a penny and he renders me the beggarly thanks. Come, sing. And you that will not, hold your tongues.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, if I've ever thanked a man, I'll thank you now. But two men complimenting each other is like two baboons getting together. Whenever a man compliments me, I feel like he's a beggar and I just gave him a penny - an embarrassing exchange. Come on, sing - and those of you who won't sing, shut up.

paragraphs.original: Well, I'll end the song. - Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree. - He hath been all this day to look you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'll finish the song I started. - Meanwhile, sirs, set the table. The duke will drink under this tree. - He's been looking for you all day, you know.

paragraphs.original: And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is too disputable for my company. I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them. Come, warble, come.
paragraphs.translated: And I've been avoiding him all day. He's too argumentative for me. I think of as many things as he does, but I just thank heaven and don't show off about it. Come, warble for me.

paragraphs.original:
(singing)
(singing)
Who doth ambition shun
Who doth ambition shun
And loves to live i' th' sun,
And loves to live i' th' sun,
Seeking the food he eats
Seeking the food he eats
And pleased with what he gets,
And pleased with what he gets,
Come hither, come hither, come hither.
Come hither, come hither, come hither.
Here shall he see
Here shall he see
No enemy
No enemy
But winter and rough weather.
But winter and rough weather.

(singing)
(singing)
Whoever shuns ambition
Whoever shuns ambition
And loves to live in the sun,
And loves to live in the sun,
Hunting the food he eats
Hunting the food he eats

Pleased with what he finds,
Come here, come here, come here.
Come here, come here, come here.

Here he will findNo enemy

But winter and rough weather.

paragraphs.original: I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
paragraphs.translated: I wrote a verse to this tune, though it's not very imaginative. I'll give it you.

paragraphs.original: What's that "ducdame"?
paragraphs.translated:
What's that word "
ducdame"?
ducdame"?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a circle. I'll go sleep if I can. If I cannot, I'll rail against all the first-born of Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: It's a Greek invocation, calling fools into a circle. I'm going to take a nap, if I can - if I can't, I'll curse all the first-born children of Egypt.

paragraphs.original: And I'll go seek the duke. His banquet is prepared.
paragraphs.translated: And I'll go find the duke; his banquet is ready.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They all exit in separate directions.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and ADAM enter.

paragraphs.original:
Dear master, I can go no further. Oh, I die for food. Here lie
I down and measure out my grave. Farewell, kind master.
paragraphs.translated: Dear master, I can't go any farther. Oh, I'm dying of hunger. I'll lie down here and measure out my grave. Farewell, kind master.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, Adam? No greater heart in thee? Live a little, comfort a little, cheer thyself a little. If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers. For my sake, be comfortable. Hold death awhile at the arm's end. I will here be with thee presently, and if I bring thee not something to eat, I will give thee leave to die. But if thou diest before I come, thou art a mocker of my labor. Well said. Thou look'st cheerly, and I'll be with thee quickly. Yet thou liest in the bleak air. Come, I will bear thee to some shelter, and thou shalt not die for lack of a dinner if there live anything in this desert. Cheerly, good Adam.
paragraphs.translated: Hey, what's this, Adam? No braver than this? Live a little, be comforted a little, cheer up a little. If I can find any animal in this wild forest, I'll either be food for it or bring it as food for you. You're not as close to death as you think you are. For my sake, make yourself comfortable; keep death at arm's length for a while. I'll be back soon, and if I haven't brought you anything to eat, I will give you permission to die. But if you die before I return, you'll have made a mockery of my efforts. There we go! You look happier already, and I'll be back quickly. But you're lying out in the cold. Come, I'll carry you to shelter. And you won't die for lack of dinner, if there's anything at all to eat in this desert-like forest. Cheer up, good Adam.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and LORDS like outlaws.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and LORDS enter, dressed like outlaws.

paragraphs.original:
I think he be transformed into a beast,
For I can nowhere find him like a man.
paragraphs.translated: I think he must have turned into an animal, because I can't find him anywhere looking like a man.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, he is but even now gone hence.
Here was he merry, hearing of a song.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, he just left here. He was happy here, listening to a song.

paragraphs.original:
If he, compact of jars, grow musical,
We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
Go seek him. Tell him I would speak with him.
paragraphs.translated: If that man, who's made up of conflicts, becomes musical, then there must be something wrong with the universe. Go find him. Tell him I want to speak with him.

paragraphs.original: Enter JAQUES
paragraphs.translated: JAQUES enters.

paragraphs.original: He saves my labor by his own approach.
paragraphs.translated: He saved me the trouble: here he comes.

paragraphs.original:
Why, how now, monsieur? What a life is this
That your poor friends must woo your company?
What, you look merrily.
paragraphs.translated: Well, what's going on, mister? What kind of life do you lead that your poor friends must beg for your company? What, you look amused.

paragraphs.original:
A fool, a fool, I met a fool i' th' forest,
A motley fool. A miserable world!
As I do live by food, I met a fool,
Who laid him down and basked him in the sun
And railed on Lady Fortune in good terms,
In good set terms, and yet a motley fool.
"Good morrow, fool," quoth I. "No, sir," quoth he,
"Call me not 'fool' till heaven hath sent me fortune."
paragraphs.translated:
A fool, a fool! I met a
fool in the forest, wearing motley. What a miserable world! As sure as I eat to stay alive, I met a fool who was lying in the sun and complaining about his fortune. He spoke smartly, though he was a fool. "Good morning, fool," I said. "No, sir," he said, "don't call me a fool until heaven has sent me my
fortune."
fool



fortune

paragraphs.original:
And then he drew a dial from his poke
And, looking on it with lackluster eye,
Says very wisely, "It is ten o'clock.
Thus we may see," quoth he, "how the world wags.
'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine,
And after one hour more 'twill be eleven.
And so from hour to hour we ripe and ripe,
And then from hour to hour we rot and rot,
And thereby hangs a tale." When I did hear
The motley fool thus moral on the time,
My lungs began to crow like chanticleer
That fools should be so deep-contemplative,
And I did laugh sans intermission
An hour by his dial. O noble fool!
A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.
paragraphs.translated: Then he pulled a watch from his bag and, looking at it solemnly, said, "It's ten o'clock. This way, we can see how the world moves. Only an hour ago it was nine, and in another hour it will be eleven. And so, from hour to hour we ripen, and from hour to hour we rot. And there's a story behind that." When I heard that motley fool moralizing on the subject of time, I began to crow like a rooster. Hearing a fool speaking so contemplatively made me laugh non-stop for an hour. Oh, noble fool! A worthy fool! Motley is the only thing to wear.

paragraphs.original: What fool is this?
paragraphs.translated: Who is this fool?

paragraphs.original:
O worthy fool! - One that hath been a courtier
And says, "If ladies be but young and fair,
They have the gift to know it." And in his brain,
Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit
After a voyage, he hath strange places crammed
With observation, the which he vents
In mangled forms. Oh, that I were a fool!
I am ambitious for a motley coat.
paragraphs.translated:
A worthy fool! He's been a courtier and says, "If ladies are young and pretty, they always know it." His
brain is dry as a sailor's biscuit and crammed with all sorts of strange observations, which he presents in mangled fashion. Oh, I wish I were a fool! I'm ambitious for one of those motley coats.
brain

paragraphs.original: Thou shalt have one.
paragraphs.translated: You shall have one.

paragraphs.original:
It is my only suit,
Provided that you weed your better judgments
Of all opinion that grows rank in them
That I am wise. I must have liberty
Withal, as large a charter as the wind,
To blow on whom I please, for so fools have.
And they that are most gallèd with my folly,
They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?
The "why" is plain as way to parish church:
He that a fool doth very wisely hit
Doth very foolishly, although he smart,
Not to seem senseless of the bob. If not,
The wise man's folly is anatomized
Even by the squand'ring glances of the fool.
Invest me in my motley. Give me leave
To speak my mind, and I will through and through
Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world,
If they will patiently receive my medicine.
paragraphs.translated: That's all I ask from you, as long as you promise to rid yourself of any rotten idea that I am wise. Like the wind, I must have the freedom to blast anyone I please, as fools do. And whoever is most irritated by my foolishness has to laugh the hardest. Why, sir, must he? Well, it's as plain as the beaten path to a parish church. Any person who thinks I'm satirizing them would be stupid if they didn't pretend not to be hurt by my joke. Otherwise, they'd be admitting I was talking about them, and the fool would expose the wise man's foolishness with a joke that wasn't even meant for him. Dress me up in motley. Let me speak my mind, and I'll rid the world of its sickness - if it will only tolerate my medicine.

paragraphs.original: Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.
paragraphs.translated: To hell with you! I know what you'd do.

paragraphs.original: What, for a counter, would I do but good?
paragraphs.translated: What would I do besides good?

paragraphs.original:
Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin,
For thou thyself hast been a libertine,
As sensual as the brutish sting itself,
And all th' embossèd sores and headed evils
That thou with license of free foot hast caught
Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
paragraphs.translated: You would be committing a wicked sin by chiding other people for sinning, because you yourself have been a terrible sinner, as carnal in your appetites as lust itself, and all the swollen pustules of sin that you acquired in your freedom you now want to burst and shoot back into the world at large.

paragraphs.original:
Why, who cries out on pride
That can therein tax any private party?
Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea
Till that the weary very means do ebb?
paragraphs.translated: But if I cry out against pride in general, how can anyone say I'm accusing a particular person? Aren't we talking about a problem as vast as the sea, that keeps flowing until all the wealth in the world is almost used up by everyone showing off?

paragraphs.original:
What woman in the city do I name,
When that I say the city-woman bears
The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?
Who can come in and say that I mean her,
When such a one as she such is her neighbor?
Or what is he of basest function
That says his bravery is not of my cost,
Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits
His folly to the mettle of my speech?
There then. How then, what then? Let me see wherein
My tongue hath wronged him. If it do him right,
Then he hath wronged himself. If he be free,
Why then my taxing like a wild goose flies
Unclaimed of any man. But who comes here?
paragraphs.translated:
What woman in the city am I talking about when I say that the clothes on a city-woman's unworthy back are rich enough to suit a prince? Who can say I mean just her when all her neighbors are exactly like her? And when some lowlife protests that his fancy clothes aren't my problem, isn't he basically admitting that I'm talking about him? Well, then. Tell me how I've wronged him. If I was right about him, he's the one who's done wrong. If he isn't guilty of the faults I'm talking about, well then, my accusations fly by like wild geese, whom no one owns, since they don't apply to any man. But who is this?
his

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO, with his sword drawn
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO enters with his sword drawn.

paragraphs.original: Forbear, and eat no more.
paragraphs.translated: Stop, and eat no more.

paragraphs.original: Why, I have eat none yet.
paragraphs.translated: But I haven't eaten anything yet.

paragraphs.original: Nor shalt not till necessity be served.
paragraphs.translated: And you won't until the needy eat.

paragraphs.original: Of what kind should this cock come of?
paragraphs.translated: What kind of fighting cock is this?

paragraphs.original:
Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress
Or else a rude despiser of good manners,
That in civility thou seem'st so empty?
paragraphs.translated: Are you acting so boldly from hardship or because you despise good manners? Why do you seem so lacking in civility?

paragraphs.original:
You touched my vein at first. The thorny point
Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
Of smooth civility, yet am I inland bred
And know some nurture. But forbear, I say.
He dies that touches any of this fruit
Till I and my affairs are answerèd.
paragraphs.translated: You were right the first time. My piercing distress has stripped me of smooth manners. But I wasn't raised in the forest, and I was somewhat well-bred. But stop, I say. Whoever eats this fruit before I've been taken care of dies.

paragraphs.original: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.
paragraphs.translated: If you won't listen to reason, I'll have to die.

paragraphs.original:
What would you have? Your gentleness shall force
More than your force move us to gentleness.
paragraphs.translated: What would you like? Gentlemanly manners have more sway around here than force does.

paragraphs.original: I almost die for food, and let me have it.
paragraphs.translated: I'm dying for food, so let me have some.

paragraphs.original: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.
paragraphs.translated: Sit down and eat, and welcome to our table.

paragraphs.original:
Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you.
I thought that all things had been savage here,
And therefore put I on the countenance
Of stern commandment. But whate'er you are
That in this desert inaccessible,
Under the shade of melancholy boughs,
Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time,
If ever you have looked on better days,
If ever been where bells have knolled to church,
If ever sat at any good man's feast,
If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear
And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied,
Let gentleness my strong enforcement be,
In the which hope I blush and hide my sword.
paragraphs.translated: Do you really speak like such a gentleman? I beg your pardon. I thought everything out here was wild, which is why I acted so stern and commanding. But whoever you are - you who sit in the dark shade, losing track of time in this remote forest - if you have ever seen better days or been to church or sat at a man's table for a feast or wiped a tear from your eye, if you know what it is to pity and be pitied, let my kindness and nobility persuade you. With that hope, I'll blush at my rudeness and put away my sword.

paragraphs.original:
True is it that we have seen better days
And have with holy bell been knolled to church,
And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes
Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered.
And therefore sit you down in gentleness,
And take upon command what help we have
That to your wanting may be ministered.
paragraphs.translated: We have in fact seen better days and been summoned to church by the ringing of the holy bell and sat at good men's feasts and cried tears of pity - therefore, sit down and take whatever will satisfy your needs.

paragraphs.original:
Then but forbear your food a little while
Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn
And give it food. There is an old poor man
Who after me hath many a weary step
Limped in pure love. Till he be first sufficed,
Oppressed with two weak evils, age and hunger,
I will not touch a bit.
paragraphs.translated: Then please, put off your eating for a little while I, like a mother doe, find my fawn and bring it food. There is a poor old man who, purely out of love, has limped after me for miles. He's burdened by two debilitating evils - age and hunger. Until he's fed, I won't eat a thing.

paragraphs.original:
Go find him out,
And we will nothing waste till you return.
paragraphs.translated: Go find him. We won't touch a thing till you return.

paragraphs.original: I thank you; and be blessed for your good comfort.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, and God bless you for your hospitality.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy.
This wide and universal theater
Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
Wherein we play in.
paragraphs.translated: You see, we're not alone in our unhappiness. This wide, universal theater has more sad plays than our own little scene.

paragraphs.original:
All the world's a stage,
And all the men and women merely players.
They have their exits and their entrances,
And one man in his time plays many parts,
His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,
Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.
Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel
And shining morning face, creeping like snail
Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,
Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad
Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier,
Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard,
Jealous in honor, sudden and quick in quarrel,
paragraphs.translated: The whole world is a stage, and all the men and women merely actors. They have their exits and their entrances, and in his lifetime a man will play many parts, his life separated into seven acts. In the first act he is an infant, whimpering and puking in his nurse's arms. Then he's the whining schoolboy, with a book bag and a bright, young face, creeping like a snail unwillingly to school. Then he becomes a lover, huffing and puffing like a furnace as he writes sad poems about his mistress's eyebrows. In the fourth act, he's a soldier, full of foreign curses, with a beard like a panther, eager to defend his honor and quick to fight.

paragraphs.original:
Seeking the bubble reputation
Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice,
In fair round belly with good capon lined,
With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,
Full of wise saws and modern instances;
And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
Into the lean and slippered pantaloon
With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,
His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide
For his shrunk shank, and his big manly voice,
Turning again toward childish treble, pipes
And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,
That ends this strange eventful history,
Is second childishness and mere oblivion,
Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.
paragraphs.translated: On the battlefield, he puts himself in front of the cannon's mouth, risking his life to seek fame that is as fleeting as a soap bubble. In the fifth act, he is a judge, with a nice fat belly from all the bribes he's taken. His eyes are stern, and he's given his beard a respectable cut. He's full of wise sayings and up-to-the-minute anecdotes: that's the way he plays his part. In the sixth act, the curtain rises on a skinny old man in slippers, glasses on his nose and a money bag at his side. The stockings he wore in his youth hang loosely on his shriveled legs now, and his bellowing voice has shrunk back down to a childish squeak. In the last scene of our play - the end of this strange, eventful history - our hero, full of forgetfulness, enters his second childhood: without teeth, without eyes, without taste, without everything.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO bearing ADAM
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO enters carrying ADAM.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome. Set down your venerable burden,
And let him feed.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome. Set the honorable old man down and let him eat.

paragraphs.original: I thank you most for him.
paragraphs.translated: I thank you very much on his behalf.

paragraphs.original:
So had you need. - 
I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.
paragraphs.translated: You had better do that. I can barely speak to thank you myself.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome. Fall to. I will not trouble you
As yet to question you about your fortunes. - 
Give us some music, and, good cousin, sing.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome. Eat. I won't trouble you yet with questions about your situation. - Some music, please, and, good friend, sing.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
Blow, blow, thou winter wind.
Blow, blow, thou winter wind.
Thou art not so unkind
Thou art not so unkind
As man's ingratitude.
As man's ingratitude.
Thy tooth is not so keen,
Thy tooth is not so keen,
Because thou art not seen,
Because thou art not seen,
Although thy breath be rude.
Although thy breath be rude.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly.
Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
Then heigh-ho, the holly.
Then heigh-ho, the holly.
This life is most jolly.
This life is most jolly.

Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,
That dost not bite so nigh
That dost not bite so nigh
As benefits forgot.
As benefits forgot.
Though thou the waters warp,
Though thou the waters warp,
Thy sting is not so sharp
Thy sting is not so sharp
As friend remembered not.
As friend remembered not.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly.

Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
Then heigh-ho, the holly.
Then heigh-ho, the holly.
This life is most jolly.
This life is most jolly.

(singing)
(singing)
Blow, blow, winter wind.
Blow, blow, winter wind.
You aren't as harsh
You aren't as harsh
As men's ingratitude.Your teeth aren't as sharp,
As men's ingratitude.Your teeth aren't as sharp,
As you are invisible,
As you are invisible,
Even though your breath is an assault.
Even though your breath is an assault.
Heigh-ho! Sing, heigh-ho! Sing to the green holly.
Heigh-ho! Sing, heigh-ho! Sing to the green holly.

Most friendship is false, most love simply foolishness.
Then heigh-ho, to the holly.
Then heigh-ho, to the holly.

This life is really jolly.
Freeze, freeze, you bitter sky,

Your bite isn't as painful

As when good deeds are forgotten.

As the friend who is forgotten.
Heigh-ho! Sing, heigh-ho! Sing to the green holly.

Most friendship is false, most love simply foolishness.
Then heigh-ho, to the holly.
Then heigh-ho, to the holly.
This life is really jolly.
This life is really jolly.

paragraphs.original:
If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son,
As you have whispered faithfully you were,
And as mine eye doth his effigies witness
Most truly limned and living in your face,
Be truly welcome hither. I am the duke
That loved your father. The residue of your fortune
Go to my cave and tell me. - Good old man,
Thou art right welcome as thy master is.
Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,
And let me all your fortunes understand.
paragraphs.translated: If you really are Sir Rowland's son, as you've just whispered to me - and I can absolutely see the likeness in your face -  you are truly welcome here. I am the duke who loved your father. Come to my cave and tell me the rest of your story. - Good old man, you are as welcome here as your master is. Give him your arm. Give me your hand, and explain your situation to me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, LORDS, and OLIVER
paragraphs.translated: DUKE FREDERICK enters, with lords and OLIVER.

paragraphs.original:
Not see him since? Sir, sir, that cannot be.
But were I not the better part made mercy,
I should not seek an absent argument
Of my revenge, thou present. But look to it:
Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is.
Seek him with candle. Bring him, dead or living,
Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more
To seek a living in our territory.
Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
Worth seizure, do we seize into our hands
Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother's mouth
Of what we think against thee.
paragraphs.translated: You haven't seen him since? Sir, sir, that can't be true. If I weren't a merciful man, I'd forget about your missing brother and punish you in his place. But do this: find your brother, wherever he is. Bring him here dead or alive within the next year, or get out off my land. I'm seizing your lands and all that you possess until your brother gives testimony that absolves you of any guilt.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, that your Highness knew my heart in this:
I never loved my brother in my life.
paragraphs.translated: I wish your Highness knew my true feelings in this matter: I have never in my life loved my brother.

paragraphs.original:
More villain thou. - Well, push him out of doors
And let my officers of such a nature
Make an extent upon his house and lands.
Do this expediently, and turn him going.
paragraphs.translated: That makes you an even bigger villain. - Well, throw him out, and have my officers seize his house and lands. Do this immediately, and send him packing.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO, with a paper
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO enters, holding a piece of paper.

paragraphs.original:
Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love.
And thou, thrice-crownéd queen of night, survey
With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,
Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway.
O Rosalind, these trees shall be my books,
And in their barks my thoughts I'll character,
That every eye which in this forest looks
Shall see thy virtue witnessed everywhere.
Run, run, Orlando, carve on every tree
The fair, the chaste, and unexpressive she.
paragraphs.translated:
Hang there on this tree, you lines of poetry, and bear witness to my love. And you,
goddess of the moon, queen of the night - with your chaste eye, from your pale home up above - watch your huntress, who has the power to control my life. Oh, Rosalind, these trees will be my books - I'll write my thoughts down on their bark. That way, everyone who passes through this forest will find your virtues everywhere. Run, run, Orlando, on every tree carve praises of her beauty, her virtue, and her inexpressibility.
goddess of the moon

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
paragraphs.translated: CORIN and TOUCHSTONE enter.

paragraphs.original: And how like you this shepherd's life, Master Touchstone?
paragraphs.translated: And how are you liking the shepherd's life, Master Touchstone?

paragraphs.original: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd's life, it is naught. In respect that it is solitary, I like it very well; but in respect that it is private, it is a very vile life. Now in respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in respect it is not in the court, it is tedious. As it is a spare life, look you, it fits my humor well; but as there is no more plenty in it, it goes much against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?
paragraphs.translated: Well, in and of itself, it is a good life, but given that it's a shepherd's life, it's worthless. In the fact that it's solitary, I enjoy it very much; but in the sense that it's private, it's terrible. Now, I'm very pleased with it being outdoors, but in its not being at the court, it is boring. Being a simple life, it suits me very well, but being a life without plenty, it doesn't suit me at all. Are you any kind of philosopher yourself, shepherd?

paragraphs.original: No more but that I know the more one sickens, the worse at ease he is, and that he that wants money, means, and content is without three good friends; that the property of rain is to wet, and fire to burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep; and that a great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that he that hath learned no wit by nature nor art may complain of good breeding or comes of a very dull kindred.
paragraphs.translated: Only in that I know that the sicker one gets, the worse one feels, and that the man who lacks money, employment, and happiness is without three good friends. I know that rain makes things wet and fire burns things. I know that a good pasture makes sheep fat, that the main cause of night is the absence of sun, and that the man who isn't smart by nature and hasn't learned anything from his schooling will complain of his lack of good manners, or he comes from very dull parents indeed.

paragraphs.original: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in court, shepherd?
paragraphs.translated: You're a natural-born philosopher! Were you ever at court, shepherd?

paragraphs.original: No, truly.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, no.

paragraphs.original: Then thou art damned.
paragraphs.translated: Then you are damned.

paragraphs.original: Nay, I hope.
paragraphs.translated: I hope not.

paragraphs.original: Truly, thou art damned, like an ill-roasted egg, all on one side.
paragraphs.translated:
Yep, you're damned like a roasted
egg: all on one side.
egg:

paragraphs.original: For not being at court? Your reason.
paragraphs.translated: I'm damned for not having been at court? Explain.

paragraphs.original: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never saw'st good manners; if thou never saw'st good manners, then thy manners must be wicked, and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art in a parlous state, shepherd.
paragraphs.translated: Well, if you were never at court, you were never exposed to good manners; if you never witnessed good manners, your manners must be wicked; wickedness is a sin, and committing sins leads to damnation. You are in a perilous state, shepherd.

paragraphs.original: Not a whit, Touchstone. Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court. You told me you salute not at the court but you kiss your hands. That courtesy would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds.
paragraphs.translated: Not at all, Touchstone. The good manners of the court look as silly in the country as country behavior is laughable at the court. You told me that you don't salute at the court but kiss hands. Now, if courtiers were shepherds, that kind of courtesy would be unclean.

paragraphs.original: Instance, briefly. Come, instance.
paragraphs.translated: Give a quick example. Come, explain.

paragraphs.original: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their fells, you know, are greasy.
paragraphs.translated: Why, because we're always handling our ewes, and their fleece, as you know, is greasy.

paragraphs.original: Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man? Shallow, shallow. A better instance, I say. Come.
paragraphs.translated: What, don't courtiers' hands sweat? And isn't a sheep's grease as wholesome as a man's sweat? That's a poor example. A better example - come on.

paragraphs.original: Besides, our hands are hard.
paragraphs.translated: Besides, our hands are hard and calloused.

paragraphs.original: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again. A more sounder instance. Come.
paragraphs.translated: Then your lips will feel them more quickly. Shallow thinking, yet again. Come on.

paragraphs.original: And they are often tarred over with the surgery of our sheep; and would you have us kiss tar? The courtier's hands are perfumed with civet.
paragraphs.translated:
Our hands are often covered in tar, from performing surgery on our
sheep.Would you have us country folks kiss each other's tarred hands? Courtiers' hands are perfumed.
sheep

paragraphs.original: Most shallow man. Thou worms' meat in respect of a good piece of flesh, indeed. Learn of the wise and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance, shepherd.
paragraphs.translated: You shallow thinker! You worthless man! You are about as much of a thinker as worm's meat is a nice steak. Learn from the wise, and comprehend: the courtier's perfume is made from cat discharge - much more disgusting than tar. Fix your example, shepherd.

paragraphs.original: You have too courtly a wit for me. I'll rest.
paragraphs.translated: Your wit is too courtly for me. I'll rest now.

paragraphs.original: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee, shallow man. God make incision in thee; thou art raw.
paragraphs.translated: You're going to rest while you're still damned? God help you, foolish man. Pray God does some surgery on you: you need to be fixed.

paragraphs.original: Sir, I am a true laborer. I earn that I eat, get that I wear, owe no man hate, envy no man's happiness, glad of other men's good, content with my harm, and the greatest of my pride is to see my ewes graze and my lambs suck.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I'm a true, simple laborer: I earn what I eat, get what I wear, hate no man, envy no man's happiness, am happy for other men's good fortune and satisfied with my own bad fortune, and the source of my greatest pride is watching my ewes graze and my lambs feed.

paragraphs.original: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram, out of all reasonable match. If thou be'st not damned for this, the devil himself will have no shepherds. I cannot see else how thou shouldst 'scape.
paragraphs.translated: That's another sin arising from your ignorance: you bring ewes and rams together and make your living by their copulation. You act as a pimp to a young ewe by forcing her to have sex with a crooked-headed, horny old ram - a totally unreasonable match. If you're not damned for that, then the devil must be keeping shepherds out of hell; I can't see how else you can hope to escape.

paragraphs.original: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress's brother.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes young Mr. Ganymede, my new mistress's brother.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND, with a paper, reading
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND enters, reading from a sheet of paper.

paragraphs.original:
(as Ganymede, reading) From the east to western Ind,
(as Ganymede, reading)
No jewel is like Rosalind.
Her worth being mounted on the wind,
Through all the world bears Rosalind.
All the pictures fairest lined
Are but black to Rosalind.
Let no fair be kept in mind
But the fair of Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading, as Ganymede) From the far east to the west Indies
(reading, as Ganymede)
There is no jewel like Rosalind.
Her worth is carried on the wind
And it blows throughout the world, carrying the name of Rosalind.
All the most beautiful paintings
Are black when compared to Rosalind.
Don't think of any beauty
But the beauty of Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: I'll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and suppers and sleeping hours excepted. It is the right butter-women's rank to market.
paragraphs.translated: I could rhyme like that for eight years in a row, excepting meal times and sleeping hours. That awful, plodding rhyme sounded like a row of dairy women stomping off to market.

paragraphs.original: Out, fool.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, stop, fool.

paragraphs.original:
For a taste:
If a hart do lack a hind,
Let him seek out Rosalind.
If the cat will after kind,
So, be sure, will Rosalind.
Winter garments must be lined,
So must slender Rosalind.
They that reap must sheaf and bind,
Then to cart with Rosalind.
Sweetest nut hath sourest rind;
Such a nut is Rosalind.
He that sweetest rose will find
Must find love's prick, and Rosalind.
This is the very false gallop of verses. Why do you infect yourself with them?
paragraphs.translated:
Let me try:
If there's a buck who needs a doe
Tell him Rosalind will do.
A cat in heat will look for a mate,
And Rosalind certainly will too.
Winter garments need to be filled with something,
And so does skinny Rosalind.
After you harvest, you have to sheaf and bind
So throw ripe Rosalind on the harvest cart.
The sweetest nut has the sourest rind
And Rosalind is that kind of nut.
The man who finds the sweetest rose
Will be pricked by it, and by Rosalind.
This is exactly the false way that verses gallop along. Why bother with them?

paragraphs.original: Peace, you dull fool. I found them on a tree.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet, you stupid fool. I found them on a tree.

paragraphs.original: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.
paragraphs.translated: Well, the tree bears rotten fruit.

paragraphs.original: I'll graft it with you, and then I shall graft it with a medlar. Then it will be the earliest fruit i' th' country, for you'll be rotten ere you be half ripe, and that's the right virtue of the medlar.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll graft you onto that tree, and when I do I'll be grafting onto it a
medlar. The fruit the tree bears will be the earliest to ripen in the country because, God knows, you'll be rotten before you're half-ripe, which is how medlars are.
medlar



you'll

paragraphs.original: You have said, but whether wisely or no, let the forest judge.
paragraphs.translated: All right, you've had your say, but we'll let the forest judge whether or not you spoke wisely.

paragraphs.original: Enter CELIA, with a writing
paragraphs.translated: CELIA enters with a piece of paper.

paragraphs.original: Peace. Here comes my sister reading. Stand aside.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet! Here comes my cousin, reading something; step aside.

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena, reads) Why should this a desert be?
(as Aliena, reads)
For it is unpeopled? No.
Tongues I'll hang on every tree
That shall civil sayings show.
Some how brief the life of man
Runs his erring pilgrimage,
That the stretching of a span
Buckles in his sum of age;
Some of violated vows
'Twixt the souls of friend and friend.
But upon the fairest boughs,
Or at every sentence end,
Will I "Rosalinda" write,
Teaching all that read to know
The quintessence of every sprite
Heaven would in little show.
Therefore heaven nature charged
That one body should be filled
With all graces wide-enlarged.
Nature presently distilled
Helen's cheek, but not her heart,
Cleopatra's majesty,
Atalanta's better part,
Sad Lucretia's modesty.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading, as Aliena) Why should this place be a desert
(reading, as Aliena)
Just because there are no people in it? No,
I'll hang these poems on every tree,
And they will voice the thoughts of a city.
Some will be about how man's brief life
is spent in wandering,
his entire life contained
in the width of an open hand.
Some poems will be about betrayals
Committed by friends.
But on the prettiest branches
Or at the end of every sentence
I'll write "Rosalinda,"
Teaching everyone who can read
that the essence of every spirit
Is contained in this one woman.
Heaven commanded Nature
To fill her one body
With all the graces that women contain.
Nature took
Helen's
beautiful face, but not her fickle heart;
beautiful



Cleopatra's majesty,
The best of Atalanta,
And unhappy Lucretia's modesty.

paragraphs.original:
Thus Rosalind of many parts
By heavenly synod was devised,
Of many faces, eyes, and hearts
To have the touches dearest prized.
Heaven would that she these gifts should have
And I to live and die her slave.
paragraphs.translated:
So, by heaven's decree, Rosalind
Was composed
Of different faces, eyes, and hearts,
so that she might have the most prized touches of all.
Heaven wanted Rosalind to have these gifts
And me to live and die as her slave.

paragraphs.original: O most gentle Jupiter, what tedious homily of love have you wearied your parishioners withal, and never cried, "Have patience, good people."
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Lord - what tedious sayings about love have you been wearing out your congregation with? Shouldn't you have warned, "Be patient, good people"?

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena) How now? - Back, friends. - Shepherd, go off a little. - Go with him, sirrah.
(as Aliena)
paragraphs.translated: What are you saying? - Shoo, Shepherd, go a little ways away. - Go with him, Touchstone.

paragraphs.original: Come, shepherd, let us make an honorable retreat, though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and scrippage.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, shepherd, let's make an honorable retreat, though not with all the trappings of a full army; just with a shepherd's pouch and the stuff he puts in it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CORIN and TOUCHSTONE
paragraphs.translated: CORIN and TOUCHSTONE exit.

paragraphs.original: Didst thou hear these verses?
paragraphs.translated: Were you listening to these verses?

paragraphs.original: Oh, yes, I heard them all, and more too, for some of them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh yes, I heard them all, and more, too. Some of those lines had more feet than the
verses could bear.
verses

paragraphs.original: That's no matter. The feet might bear the verses.
paragraphs.translated: That's not a problem: the feet can bear the verses.

paragraphs.original: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.
paragraphs.translated:
Sure, but these feet were
lame, and couldn't have stood up without the support of the verses. They stood lamely in the verse.
lame

paragraphs.original: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be hanged and carved upon these trees?
paragraphs.translated: But did you listen to all that poetry without even wondering about what your name is doing on all these trees?

paragraphs.original: I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder before you came, for look here what I found on a palm tree. I was never so berhymed since Pythagoras' time, that I was an Irish rat, which I can hardly remember.
paragraphs.translated:
I was working through my wonder when you arrived. Look at what I found on a palm tree. I haven't been rhymed about like this since my past life, when I was an
Irish rat, but I can hardly remember that.
Irish rat

paragraphs.original: Trow you who hath done this?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know who wrote these?

paragraphs.original: Is it a man?
paragraphs.translated: Was it a man?

paragraphs.original: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck. Change you color?
paragraphs.translated: And he had a chain that once belonged to you hanging around his neck. Are you blushing?

paragraphs.original: I prithee, who?
paragraphs.translated: Please, who?

paragraphs.original: O Lord, Lord, it is a hard matter for friends to meet, but mountains may be removed with earthquakes and so encounter.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, God! It's difficult to bring two friends together, but even mountains can be moved together by earthquakes.

paragraphs.original: Nay, but who is it?
paragraphs.translated: No, who are you talking about?

paragraphs.original: Is it possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is it possible?

paragraphs.original: Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence, tell me who it is.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'm begging you now, tell me who it is.

paragraphs.original: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, this is wonderful, wonderful - just wonderful wonderful! And another wonderful, and beyond-my-ability-to-express wonderful!

paragraphs.original: Good my complexion, dost thou think though I am caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in my disposition? One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery. I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace. I would thou couldst stammer, that thou might'st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle - either too much at once, or none at all. I prithee take the cork out of thy mouth, that I may drink thy tidings.
paragraphs.translated: Good grief, do you think that just because I'm dressed like a man, I have a man's patience? Every second you delay is as long and dull as a journey to South Seas. I'm begging you, tell me who it is quickly, and speak fast. I wish you could just stammer this hidden man out of your mouth like wine out of a narrow-necked bottle: either too much at once or none at all. I'm begging you, take the cork out of your mouth so I can drink the news.

paragraphs.original: So you may put a man in your belly.
paragraphs.translated: So you want to put a man in your belly.

paragraphs.original: Is he of God's making? What manner of man? Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?
paragraphs.translated: Did God make him? I mean, what sort of man is he? Is he enough of a man to wear a hat and grow a beard ?

paragraphs.original: Nay, he hath but a little beard.
paragraphs.translated: No, he has only a little beard.

paragraphs.original: Why, God will send more, if the man will be thankful. Let me stay the growth of his beard, if thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.
paragraphs.translated: Well, eventually God will send him some more hair, if he thanks Him. I'll wait till his beard grows in, if you'll just hurry up and tell me what chin that beard is on.

paragraphs.original: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler's heels and your heart both in an instant.
paragraphs.translated: It's Orlando, who triumphed over both the wrestler and you in the same instant.

paragraphs.original: Nay, but the devil take mocking. Speak sad brow and true maid.
paragraphs.translated: Damn you for mocking me. Speak seriously and honestly.

paragraphs.original: I' faith, coz, 'tis he.
paragraphs.translated: Really, cousin, it's him.

paragraphs.original: Orlando?
paragraphs.translated: Orlando?

paragraphs.original: Orlando.
paragraphs.translated: Orlando.

paragraphs.original: Alas the day, what shall I do with my doublet and hose? What did he when thou saw'st him? What said he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What makes him here? Did he ask for me? Where remains he? How parted he with thee? And when shalt thou see him again? Answer me in one word.
paragraphs.translated: Oh no! What am I going to do in my man's clothing? What did he do when you saw him? What did he say? How did he look? Where did he go? What brings him here? Did he ask about me? Where is he staying? How did he say good-bye? And when will you see him again? Answer me in a word.

paragraphs.original: You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first. 'Tis a word too great for any mouth of this age's size. To say ay and no to these particulars is more than to answer in a catechism.
paragraphs.translated:
You'd better get me
Gargantua'smouth first. The word's too big for any mouth nowadays. Answering "yes" and "no" to all those questions would be harder than answering a
catechism.
Gargantua's



catechism

paragraphs.original: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man's apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled?
paragraphs.translated: But does he know that I'm here in the forest and dressed in men's clothing? Does he look as bright and handsome as the day we saw him wrestling?

paragraphs.original: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the propositions of a lover. But take a taste of my finding him, and relish it with good observance. I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.
paragraphs.translated: It's easier to count specks than to answer a lover's millions of questions. But taste my story, and relish it by paying attention. I found Orlando under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

paragraphs.original: It may well be called Jove's tree when it drops forth such fruit.
paragraphs.translated: That tree could be called God's tree, since it drops such wonderful fruit.

paragraphs.original: Give me audience, good madam.
paragraphs.translated: Let me talk, good lady.

paragraphs.original: Proceed.
paragraphs.translated: Go on.

paragraphs.original: There lay he, stretched along like a wounded knight.
paragraphs.translated: He lay there, stretched out like a wounded knight.

paragraphs.original: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes the ground.
paragraphs.translated: Though that must have been a pitiful sight, the ground looked beautiful.

paragraphs.original: Cry "holla" to thy tongue, I prithee. It curvets unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.
paragraphs.translated: Cry, "whoa!" to your tongue, please. It's leaping about like a frisky horse. He was dressed like a hunter.

paragraphs.original: Oh, ominous! He comes to kill my heart.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, that's ominous! He has come to kill my heart.

paragraphs.original: I would sing my song without a burden. Thou bring'st me out of tune.
paragraphs.translated: I'd like to sing my song solo. You're making me go off-key.

paragraphs.original: Do you not know I am a woman? When I think, I must speak. Sweet, say on.
paragraphs.translated: Don't you know that I'm a woman? Whatever I think, I have to say. Sweetheart, go on.

paragraphs.original: You bring me out. Soft, comes he not here?
paragraphs.translated: You've made me lose the tune. Quiet! Isn't that him heading this way?

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and JAQUES enter.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis he. Slink by, and note him.
paragraphs.translated: That's him. Let's slink off, and watch him from a hiding place.

paragraphs.original: I thank you for your company, but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone.
paragraphs.translated: Thanks for your company but, really, I would have preferred being alone.

paragraphs.original: And so had I, but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you too for your society.
paragraphs.translated: Me too, but still, for the sake of good manners, I'll say thanks for your company.

paragraphs.original: God be wi' you. Let's meet as little as we can.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye. Let's meet as little as we can.

paragraphs.original: I do desire we may be better strangers.
paragraphs.translated: I also hope that we can be better strangers.

paragraphs.original: I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in their barks.
paragraphs.translated: Please don't ruin any more trees by carving love poems on their barks.

paragraphs.original: I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them ill- favoredly.
paragraphs.translated: Please don't ruin any more of my poems by reading them so badly.

paragraphs.original: Rosalind is your love's name?
paragraphs.translated: Your love's name is Rosalind?

paragraphs.original: Yes, just.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's it.

paragraphs.original: I do not like her name.
paragraphs.translated: I don't like her name.

paragraphs.original: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was christened.
paragraphs.translated: They weren't looking to please you when they christened her.

paragraphs.original: What stature is she of?
paragraphs.translated: How tall is she?

paragraphs.original: Just as high as my heart.
paragraphs.translated: Just as tall as my heart.

paragraphs.original: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been acquainted with goldsmiths' wives and conned them out of rings?
paragraphs.translated:
You're sure full of smooth answers. Are you friendly with goldsmiths' wives, and memorized your little speeches off of their
rings?
rings?

paragraphs.original: Not so. But I answer you right painted cloth, from whence you have studied your questions.
paragraphs.translated:
No, but I can answer you just like those
painted cloths, where I suppose you memorized all your questions.
painted cloths

paragraphs.original: You have a nimble wit. I think 'twas made of Atalanta's heels. Will you sit down with me? And we two will rail against our mistress the world and all our misery.
paragraphs.translated:
You have a quick wit; I think it must be made out of
Atalanta's heels. Why don't you sit down with me? The two of us can complain about our mistress - the world - and all our miseries.
Atalanta's

paragraphs.original: I will chide no breather in the world but myself, against whom I know most faults.
paragraphs.translated: I won't blame anyone in this world but myself, whose faults I'm most familiar with.

paragraphs.original: The worst fault you have is to be in love.
paragraphs.translated: Your worst fault is being in love.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue. I am weary of you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, it's a fault I wouldn't trade for your best virtue. I'm tired of you.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found you.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, I was looking for a fool when I found you, so I suppose I shouldn't be surprised.
was

paragraphs.original: He is drowned in the brook. Look but in, and you shall see him.
paragraphs.translated: He's drowned in the brook: look in, and you'll see him.

paragraphs.original: There I shall see mine own figure.
paragraphs.translated: There I'll see only myself.

paragraphs.original: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.
paragraphs.translated: Which is either a fool or a nothing.

paragraphs.original: I'll tarry no longer with you. Farewell, good Signior Love.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not going to waste any more time with you. Goodbye, good Mr. Love.

paragraphs.original:
I am glad of your departure. Adieu, good Monsieur
Melancholy.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad to see you go. Adieu, good Mr. Depression.

paragraphs.original: Exit JAQUES
paragraphs.translated: JAQUES exits.

(speaking so that only CELIA can hear) I'm going to talk to him like I'm an insolent boy, so I can play a trick on him. - Can you hear me, forester?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Very well. What would you?
paragraphs.translated: Very well. What do you want?

paragraphs.original:
(as Ganymede) I pray you, what is 't o'clock?
(as Ganymede)
paragraphs.translated:
(as Ganymede) Please, what's the hour?
(as Ganymede)

paragraphs.original: You should ask me what time o' day. There's no clock in the forest.
paragraphs.translated: You should ask me what time of day it is, instead. There's no clock here in the forest.

paragraphs.original: Then there is no true lover in the forest, else sighing every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot of time as well as a clock.
paragraphs.translated: Then there must be no lovers in the forest, either, because they're as good as a clock, marking the lazy foot of time with a sigh every minute and a groan every hour.

paragraphs.original: And why not the swift foot of time? Had not that been as proper?
paragraphs.translated: Why didn't you say "the swift steps" of time instead of the "lazy foot"? Wouldn't that have been just as appropriate?

paragraphs.original: By no means, sir. Time travels in diverse paces with diverse persons. I'll tell you who time ambles withal, who time trots withal, who time gallops withal, and who he stands still withal.
paragraphs.translated: No, not at all, sir. Time travels at different speeds for different people. I can tell you who time strolls for, who it trots for, who it gallops for, and who it stops cold for.

paragraphs.original: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
paragraphs.translated: Okay, who does it trot for?

paragraphs.original: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the contract of her marriage and the day it is solemnized. If the interim be but a se'nnight, time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of seven year.
paragraphs.translated: Well, it trots for a young woman between the time she gets engaged and the time she marries: the time that's passed may only be a week, but it always feels like seven years.

paragraphs.original: Who ambles time withal?
paragraphs.translated: Who does time amble for?

paragraphs.original: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily because he cannot study and the other lives merrily because he feels no pain - the one lacking the burden of lean and wasteful learning, the other knowing no burden of heavy tedious penury. These time ambles withal.
paragraphs.translated: For a priest who doesn't know his Latin or a rich man who is free from the gout. The one sleeps easily because he isn't up late studying and the other lives merrily because he's free from pain. The first lacks the burden of intense, exhausting study, and the second is spared the burden of heavy, exhausting poverty. Time ambles for both men.

paragraphs.original: Who doth he gallop withal?
paragraphs.translated: Who does it gallop for?

paragraphs.original: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.
paragraphs.translated: For a thief on his way to the gallows. Such a man walks as slowly as possible and, even so, gets there too soon.

paragraphs.original: Who stays it still withal?
paragraphs.translated: Who does it stand still for?

paragraphs.original: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between term and term, and then they perceive not how time moves.
paragraphs.translated: For lawyers on vacation, because they sleep their holidays away, with no sense of how time moves.

paragraphs.original: Where dwell you, pretty youth?
paragraphs.translated: Where do you live, pretty young man?

paragraphs.original: With this shepherdess, my sister, here in the skirts of the forest like fringe upon a petticoat.
paragraphs.translated: With this shepherdess, my sister, on the outskirts of the forest. We live like fringe on the edges of a petticoat.

paragraphs.original: Are you native of this place?
paragraphs.translated: Were you born here?

paragraphs.original: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.
paragraphs.translated: Just like the rabbit, who lives where she is born.

paragraphs.original: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
paragraphs.translated: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this.

paragraphs.original: I have been told so of many. But indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland man, one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in love. I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.
paragraphs.translated: Many people have told me so. Actually, an old religious uncle of mine taught me how to speak, and he was brought up in the city. He knew too much about courtship, because he fell in love back there, and when he came here he constantly lectured against it. Thank God I'm not a woman and afflicted with all the giddiness that troubles that entire sex.

paragraphs.original: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid to the charge of women?
paragraphs.translated: What were the primary evils he claimed women were guilty of?

paragraphs.original: There were none principal. They were all like one another as half-pence are, every one fault seeming monstrous till his fellow fault came to match it.
paragraphs.translated: There were no primary ones. All of women's faults are as alike as one half-pence is to another. Each of a woman's faults seems monstrous until you're presented with the next one, which is just as bad.

paragraphs.original: I prithee, recount some of them.
paragraphs.translated: Please, tell me some of them.

paragraphs.original: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that are sick. There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with carving "Rosalind" on their barks, hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of Rosalind. If I could meet that fancy- monger I would give him some good counsel, for he seems to have the quotidian of love upon him.
paragraphs.translated: No, I won't give my medicine away to anyone but the sick. There's a man haunting this forest who abuses the trees by carving "Rosalind" on their barks. He hangs his odes on the hawthorns and his elegies on the brambles - each of these poems praising to the heavens one "Rosalind." Now if I could find this man, this dream-catcher, I would give him some good advice, because he is truly love-sick.

paragraphs.original: I am he that is so love-shaked. I pray you tell me your remedy.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'm the man you're speaking of. Please, tell me your cure.

paragraphs.original: There is none of my uncle's marks upon you. He taught me how to know a man in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.
paragraphs.translated: But you don't have any of the symptoms my uncle told me about. He taught me how to recognize a man in love, and you're not a prisoner of love, I'm sure.

paragraphs.original: What were his marks?
paragraphs.translated: What did he say the symptoms were?

paragraphs.original: A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a beard neglected, which you have not - but I pardon you for that, for simply your having in beard is a younger brother's revenue. Then your hose should be ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe untied, and everything about you demonstrating a careless desolation. But you are no such man. You are rather point-device in your accouterments, as loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.
paragraphs.translated: A thin face, which you don't have; a sleepless, sunken eye, which you don't have; an irritable temper, which you don't have; a neglected beard, which you don't have - but that might not be so telling, since you don't have much beard anyway. Your stockings should be falling down around your ankles, your hat flying off your head, your sleeves unbuttoned, your shoes untied, and everything about you demonstrating carelessness and misery. But you're no such man. You're so neat and well put-together that you look like you love yourself more than anyone else.

paragraphs.original: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.
paragraphs.translated: Young boy, I wish I could make you believe that I'm in love.

paragraphs.original: Me believe it? You may as soon make her that you love believe it, which I warrant she is apter to do than to confess she does. That is one of the points in the which women still give the lie to their consciences. But, in good sooth, are you he that hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?
paragraphs.translated: Make me believe it? You might as well make the one you love believe it, which she's more likely to do than admit that she does - that's one of the ways that women fool their own consciences. But really, are you the one who's been hanging on the trees those poems that speak so admiringly of Rosalind?

paragraphs.original: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.
paragraphs.translated: I swear to you by Rosalind's own pretty hand that I am that unfortunate man.

paragraphs.original: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?
paragraphs.translated: Are you really as in love as your poems declare?

paragraphs.original: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.
paragraphs.translated: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much I love her.

paragraphs.original: Love is merely a madness and, I tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do, and the reason why they are not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love, too. Yet I profess curing it by counsel.
paragraphs.translated: Love is merely a form of insanity, and I tell you, lovers deserve the nuthouse just like crazy people do. The only reason they don't get punished and cured is that the disease is so commonplace that the nuthouse nurses are usually suffering from it, too. But I promise it can be cured with some guidance.

paragraphs.original: Did you ever cure any so?
paragraphs.translated: Have you ever cured anyone this way before?

paragraphs.original: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine me his love, his mistress, and I set him every day to woo me; at which time would I, being but a moonish youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable, longing and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, shallow, inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles; for every passion something, and for no passion truly anything, as boys and women are, for the most part, cattle of this color; would now like him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now weep for him, then spit at him, that I drave my suitor from his mad humor of love to a living humor of madness, which was to forswear the full stream of the world and to live in a nook merely monastic. And thus I cured him, and this way will I take upon me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep's heart, that there shall not be one spot of love in 't.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, one, and this is how I did it. He had to imagine that I was the girl he was in love with. I made him woo me every day. When he did, being the changeable boy I am, I'd mope, act effeminate, switch moods, long for him, like him, be proud and standoffish, be dreamy, full of mannerisms, unpredictable, full of tears and then smiles; be passionate about everything, then nothing. Most boys and women act just like this. I'd like him one minute and despise him the next; cry for him, then spit at him - until finally I drove love out and anger in. He abandoned the world, and hid himself away in a monastery. So I cured him, and I'll cure you just the same, leaving you as clean as a sheep's heart, without one spot of love in you.

paragraphs.original: I would not be cured, youth.
paragraphs.translated: I don't want to be cured, boy.

paragraphs.original: I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and come every day to my cote and woo me.
paragraphs.translated: I could cure you, if you just called me Rosalind and came by my cottage every day to woo me.

paragraphs.original: Now, by the faith of my love, I will. Tell me where it is.
paragraphs.translated: By my faith in love, I will, then. Tell me where you live.

paragraphs.original: Go with me to it, and I'll show it you; and by the way you shall tell me where in the forest you live. Will you go?
paragraphs.translated: Come with me, I'll show you, and along the way, you can tell me where you live. Will you come?

paragraphs.original: With all my heart, good youth.
paragraphs.translated: Wholeheartedly, good young man.

paragraphs.original: Nay, you must call me Rosalind. - Come, sister, will you go?
paragraphs.translated: No, you have to call me Rosalind. - Sister, you're coming?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY, and JAQUES behind
paragraphs.translated: TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY enter, with JAQUES following unseen.

paragraphs.original: Come apace, good Audrey. I will fetch up your goats, Audrey. And how, Audrey? Am I the man yet? Doth my simple feature content you?
paragraphs.translated: Come on, sweet Audrey. I'll get your goats, Audrey. Well now, what do you think, Audrey? Am I the man for you, Audrey? Do my simple features please you?

paragraphs.original: Your features, Lord warrant us! What features?
paragraphs.translated: Your features, God help us! What features?

paragraphs.original: I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, I'm out here with you and your
goats, in the same way that the witty poet Ovid was abandoned to the barbaric Goths.
goats

paragraphs.original:
(aside) O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove in a thatched house.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Oh, knowledge put to such bad use is worse than a god cooped up in a hut.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: When a man's verses cannot be understood nor a man's good wit seconded with the forward child, understanding, it strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a little room. Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
paragraphs.translated: When a man's jokes fall that flat, it's as depressing as getting a large bill for a short stay in a little room. Really, Audrey, I wish you were more poetical.

paragraphs.original: I do not know what "poetical" is. Is it honest in deed and word? Is it a true thing?
paragraphs.translated: I don't know what "poetical" means. Is it "chaste in word and action"? Does it mean being truthful?

paragraphs.original: No, truly, for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.
paragraphs.translated: Not really, for the truest poetry is often the most artificial. Lovers are fond of poetry and often concoct great lies in their poems.

paragraphs.original: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?
paragraphs.translated: But you still wish the gods had made me poetical?

paragraphs.original: I do, truly, for thou swear'st to me thou art honest. Now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst feign.
paragraphs.translated: I do, in fact. Right now you swear to me that you are a virgin; if you were a poet, I might have some hope you were lying.

paragraphs.original: Would you not have me honest?
paragraphs.translated: What, you don't want me to be chaste?

paragraphs.original: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favored, for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.
