paragraphs.translated: Not really, unless you were ugly. Chastity and beauty together in one woman is like sweetening sugar with honey.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) A material fool.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) A sensible fool.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Well, I am not fair, and therefore I pray the gods make me honest.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'm not beautiful, so I hope that I can at least be chaste.

paragraphs.original: Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were to put good meat into an unclean dish.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but wasting chastity on a dirty slut is like putting good meat in a dirty dish.

paragraphs.original: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not a slut - I keep myself clean - but I thank God I am ugly.

paragraphs.original: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness; sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it may be, I will marry thee; and to that end I have been with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar of the next village, who hath promised to meet me in this place of the forest and to couple us.
paragraphs.translated: Well, praise the Lord you're ugly. Maybe sluttishness will follow. Be that as it may, I'm going to marry you. To that end, I've spoken with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar from the next village, and he's promised to meet us here and marry us.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I would fain see this meeting.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) This I'd like to see.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Well, the gods give us joy.
paragraphs.translated: Well, God bless this marriage!

paragraphs.original: Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart, stagger in this attempt, for here we have no temple but the wood, no assembly but horn-beasts. But what though? Courage. As horns are odious, they are necessary. It is said, "Many a man knows no end of his goods." Right: many a man has good horns and knows no end of them.
paragraphs.translated:
Amen. You know, some men, who have fear in their hearts, might falter at this point. After all, these woods aren't a proper
church, and there's no congregation here but horned animals. But who cares? I'll be brave. Horns may be hateful, but they're also necessary.
church



They say, "Many a man doesn't know the full extent of what he owns." Exactly: many a man will see no end to the horns his wife furnishes him with.

paragraphs.original: Well, that is the dowry of his wife; 'tis none of his own getting. Horns? Even so. Poor men alone? No, no. The noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man therefore blessed? No. As a walled town is more worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a married man more honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor. And by how much defense is better than no skill, by so much is a horn more precious than to want.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that's what the wife brings to the marriage. He didn't do anything to get them. Horns? Well, there they are. Only for poor men? No, no. The nobleman's are as huge as the underfed villager's. Is the single man lucky, then? No. Just as a town protected by a wall around it is worth more than a low-lying village, a married man's horned forehead is more honorable than a bachelor's bare forehead. Just as it's better to be skilled at self-defense than it is to avoid fighting, it's better to risk a horn by marrying. Here comes Sir Oliver.

paragraphs.original: Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
paragraphs.translated: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT enters.

paragraphs.original: Here comes Sir Oliver. - Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met. Will you dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel?
paragraphs.translated: Sir Oliver Martext, we're glad to see you. Will you marry us here, under this tree, or should we follow you to your chapel?

paragraphs.original: Is there none here to give the woman?
paragraphs.translated: Is there anyone to give the bride away?

paragraphs.original: I will not take her on gift of any man.
paragraphs.translated: I don't want to take another man's second-hand goods.

paragraphs.original: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.
paragraphs.translated: No, someone has to give her away or the marriage isn't legal.

paragraphs.original:
(advancing) Proceed, proceed. I'll give her.
(advancing)
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward) Go on, proceed - I'll give her away.
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Good even, good Monsieur What-ye-call't. How do you, sir? You are very well met. God 'ild you for your last company. I am very glad to see you. Even a toy in hand here, sir. Nay, pray be covered.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening, Mr. What'shisname. How are you, sir? We're glad to see you. God bless you for being here. I'm very glad to see you. This is just a trifling matter here, sir. No, no, put your hat back on.

paragraphs.original: Will you be married, motley?
paragraphs.translated: Do you want to get married, fool?

paragraphs.original: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.
paragraphs.translated: Just as the ox has his yoke, the horse its bridle, the falcon a tether, a man has his desires - to keep in check.

paragraphs.original: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush like a beggar? Get you to church, and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is. This fellow will but join you together as they join wainscot. Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.
paragraphs.translated: And, being a man of your breeding, you're going to be married under some shrubs like a beggar? Get yourself to a church and have a proper priest, who can tell you what marriage is all about, marry you. This man here will slap you two together like two pieces of wood panelling. Then one of you will warp and pull away - and there goes your marriage.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I am not in the mind but I were better to be married of him than of another, for he is not like to marry me well, and not being well married, it will be a good excuse for me hereafter to leave my wife.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I'd rather have this guy marry us, because he is not likely to marry us well, and if we're not married properly, I'll have a better excuse later to leave my wife.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.
paragraphs.translated: Come with me and let me advise you.

paragraphs.original:
Come, sweet Audrey. We must be married, or we must live in bawdry. - Farewell, good Master Oliver, not
O sweet Oliver,
O sweet Oliver,
O brave Oliver,
O brave Oliver,
Leave me not behind thee
Leave me not behind thee
But
But
Wind away,
Wind away,
Begone, I say,
Begone, I say,
I will not to wedding with thee.
I will not to wedding with thee.
paragraphs.translated:
Come, sweet Audrey. We have to be married properly. Otherwise, we'll be living in sin. - Goodbye, Sir Oliver. We're not singing,
Oh,
sweet Oliver
Oh,
sweet Oliver



Oh, sweet Oliver
Oh, sweet Oliver
Don't leave me behind - 
Don't leave me behind - 
but,
but,
Go away, wind
Go away, wind
Go, I say,
Go, I say,
I'm not going to marry you.
I'm not going to marry you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt JAQUES, TOUCHSTONE, and AUDREY
paragraphs.translated: JAQUES, TOUCHSTONE, and AUDREY exit.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis no matter. Ne'er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't matter to me. None of these deranged rascals can shake me from my profession.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND and CELIA enter.

paragraphs.original: Never talk to me. I will weep.
paragraphs.translated: Don't talk to me. I'm going to cry.

paragraphs.original: Do, I prithee, but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead if you want, but remember that crying doesn't suit a man.

paragraphs.original: But have I not cause to weep?
paragraphs.translated: But don't I have good reason to cry?

paragraphs.original: As good cause as one would desire. Therefore weep.
paragraphs.translated: As good a reason as any. So go ahead and cry.

paragraphs.original: His very hair is of the dissembling color.
paragraphs.translated:
I mean, his
hair is even red - the same color as that lying Judas.
hair

paragraphs.original:
Something browner than Judas's. Marry, his kisses are
Judas's own children.
paragraphs.translated:
No, it's a shade browner than
Judas's - but his kisses are just like Judas's.
Judas's

paragraphs.original: I' faith, his hair is of a good color.
paragraphs.translated: No, really, his hair is a nice color.

paragraphs.original: An excellent color. Your chestnut was ever the only color.
paragraphs.translated: A very good color, this chestnut.

paragraphs.original: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.
paragraphs.translated: His kiss is as holy as bread blessed by a priest.

paragraphs.original: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana. A nun of winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously. The very ice of chastity is in them.
paragraphs.translated:
He must have bought a cast-iron pair of
Diana's lips: an elderly nun isn't anymore devoted in her kissing than he is. His kiss is cold and chaste.
Diana's

paragraphs.original: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and comes not?
paragraphs.translated: But why would he promise to come visit me this morning and then not come?

paragraphs.original: Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.
paragraphs.translated: Really, he's a total liar.

paragraphs.original: Do you think so?
paragraphs.translated: Do you think so?

paragraphs.original: Yes, I think he is not a pick-purse nor a horse-stealer, but for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as a covered goblet or a worm-eaten nut.
paragraphs.translated: Yes. He's not a pickpocket or a horse thief, but when it comes to truth in love, he's as hollow as a cup or a nut hollowed out by a worm.

paragraphs.original: Not true in love?
paragraphs.translated: You think his feelings aren't true?

paragraphs.original: Yes, when he is in, but I think he is not in.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I think they are - when he's in love. But he's not in love.

paragraphs.original: You have heard him swear downright he was.
paragraphs.translated: But you heard him swear up and down that he was.

paragraphs.original: "Was" is not "is." Besides, the oath of a lover is no stronger than the word of a tapster. They are both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends here in the forest on the duke your father.
paragraphs.translated: He "was," but that doesn't mean he is anymore. Besides, the promises of a lover are as untrustworthy as a bartender handing you an inflated tab: they both swear to their lies. He's staying in the forest with your father now.

paragraphs.original: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with him. He asked me of what parentage I was. I told him, of as good as he. So he laughed and let me go. But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando?
paragraphs.translated: I met my father in the woods yesterday and had a long conversation with him. He asked me who my parents were, and I told him they were as good as he was. He laughed at that and let me go. But why are we talking about my father, when a man like Orlando exists?

paragraphs.original: Oh, that's a brave man. He writes brave verses, speaks brave words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of his lover, as a puny tilter that spurs his horse but on one side breaks his staff like a noble goose; but all's brave that youth mounts and folly guides.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, sure, he's a brave man! He writes brave poems, speaks brave words, makes brave promises, and then breaks them just as bravely. He's like a cowardly
jouster, who breaks his lance across his opponent's shield, rather than directly against it. But everything's brave that a young man does and foolishness leads.
jouster

paragraphs.original: Enter CORIN
paragraphs.translated: CORIN enters.

paragraphs.original: Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: Who's coming here?

paragraphs.original:
Mistress and master, you have oft inquired
After the shepherd that complained of love,
Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,
Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess
That was his mistress.
paragraphs.translated: Mistress and master, you've often asked about that lovelorn shepherd you once saw me sitting with, the one who complained about the disdainful shepherdess he was in love with.

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena) Well, and what of him?
(as Aliena)
paragraphs.translated: Yes, what about him?

paragraphs.original:
If you will see a pageant truly played
Between the pale complexion of true love
And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,
Go hence a little, and I shall conduct you,
If you will mark it.
paragraphs.translated: If you'd like to see a scene played out between a man growing pale with unrequited love and a woman glowing with scorn and proud disdain, come with me a short distance and you'll witness it.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to CELIA) O, come, let us remove.
(aside to
)
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
 - (as Ganymede) Bring us to this sight, and you shall say
(as Ganymede)
I'll prove a busy actor in their play.
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only CELIA can hear) Come on, let's go. The sight of lovers nourishes whoever else is in love. (to CORIN) Bring us to this little show, and I'll take a part in their play.
(speaking so that only
can hear)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter SILVIUS and PHOEBE
paragraphs.translated: SILVIUS and PHOEBE enter.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Phoebe, do not scorn me. Do not, Phoebe.
Say that you love me not, but say not so
In bitterness. The common executioner,
Whose heart th' accustomed sight of death makes hard,
Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck
But first begs pardon. Will you sterner be
Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?
paragraphs.translated: Sweet Phoebe, do not scorn me. Do not, Phoebe. Go ahead and say you don't love me, but not so bitterly. The executioner, who's seen death so much his heart has grown hard, still says, "forgive me" before he drops the axe on the criminal's neck. Are you going to be crueler than the man who makes his living by killing?

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, behind
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN enter at the back of the stage, unseen.

paragraphs.original:
I would not be thy executioner.
I fly thee, for I would not injure thee.
Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye.
'Tis pretty, sure, and very probable
That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things,
Who shut their coward gates on atomies,
Should be called tyrants, butchers, murderers.
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart,
And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee.
Now counterfeit to swoon, why, now fall down;
Or if thou canst not, Oh, for shame, for shame,
Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers.
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee.
Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains
Some scar of it. Lean upon a rush,
The cicatrice and capable impressure
Thy palm some moment keeps. But now mine eyes,
Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not.
Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes
That can do hurt.
paragraphs.translated: I don't want to be your executioner: I'm trying to avoid you so that I won't hurt you. You tell me my eyes are murderous - that's a very pretty sentiment, and oh-so-probable, that my frail, soft eyes (which are so cowardly that they close their gates against dust) are tyrants, butchers, and murderers. I'm frowning at you with all my might right now. If my eyes can injure, let them kill you now. Go ahead. Faint, fall down - if you don't, then you're lying about my eyes being murderers. Come on, show me the wound that my eyes have caused. If you get scratched with a pin, it leaves a scar; even if you lean on a rush, it leaves an impression on your palm. But my eyes, which I've darted at you, haven't even left a mark. Now I am sure that eyes can't hurt a person.

paragraphs.original:
O dear Phoebe,
If ever - as that ever may be near - 
You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,
Then shall you know the wounds invisible
That love's keen arrows make.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, darling Phoebe, if you ever fall in love with some fresh face, then you'll know about the invisible wounds that love's sharp arrows can make.

paragraphs.original:
But till that time
Come not thou near me. And when that time comes,
Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not,
As till that time I shall not pity thee.
paragraphs.translated: Well, until that time, don't come near me. And when that time comes, then you can mock me, but please don't pity me, because I won't pity you.

paragraphs.original:
(advancing, as Ganymede) And why, I pray you? Who might be your mother,
(advancing, as Ganymede)
That you insult, exult, and all at once,
Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty - 
As, by my faith, I see no more in you
Than without candle may go dark to bed - 
Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?
Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?
I see no more in you than in the ordinary
Of nature's sale-work. - 'Od's my little life,
I think she means to tangle my eyes, too.
 - No, faith, proud mistress, hope not after it.
'Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,
Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream
That can entame my spirits to your worship.
 - You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,
Like foggy south puffing with wind and rain?
You are a thousand times a properer man
Than she a woman. 'Tis such fools as you
That makes the world full of ill-favored children.
'Tis not her glass but you that flatters her,
And out of you she sees herself more proper
Than any of her lineaments can show her.
 - But, mistress, know yourself. Down on your knees
And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love,
For I must tell you friendly in your ear,
Sell when you can; you are not for all markets.
Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer.
Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
 - So take her to thee, shepherd. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward, speaking as Ganymede) And why, please tell me? Is your mother a goddess that you would insult a wretched man, and exult over the injury you've caused him, all at the same time? You're not beautiful - really, you're not so pretty that you could go to bed with the lights on - so why must you act so proud and pitiless? Wait a minute, what's going on? Why are you looking at me like that? I don't see anything in you but nature's usual handiwork. - Oh, for God's sake, I think she also wants me to fall in love with her. No, proud woman, don't hope for that. Not even your black eyebrows, your silky black hair, your beady black eyeballs, or your yellowish-white complexion can make me worship you. You foolish shepherd: why are you following her, raining tears and puffing hot air like a foggy south wind? You are a thousand times better than she. It's fools like you who, marrying badly, fill the world with ugly children. It's not her mirror but you who insists she's beautiful. The image of herself that she gets from you is better than her actual features.
(coming forward, speaking as Ganymede)

paragraphs.original:
- But, mistress, know yourself. Down on your knees
And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love,
For I must tell you friendly in your ear,
Sell when you can; you are not for all markets.
Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer.
Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
 - So take her to thee, shepherd. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: But mistress, know yourself. Get down on your knees and thank heaven for sending you such a good man. I'm telling you, as a friend, that you should sell while the market's good - you're not going to have many more buyers. Ask this man's forgiveness, love him, and accept his offer. You're already ugly, don't make matters worse by being scornful, too. So take her, shepherd, and God bless you.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet youth, I pray you chide a year together.
I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet boy, I'd rather hear you scold me for a whole year than this man woo me for a minute.

paragraphs.original: For no ill will I bear you.
paragraphs.translated: I don't wish you any harm.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, do not fall in love with me,
For I am falser than vows made in wine.
Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,
'Tis at the tuft of olives, here hard by.
 - Will you go, sister? - Shepherd, ply her hard.
 - Come, sister. - Shepherdess, look on him better,
And be not proud. Though all the world could see,
None could be so abused in sight as he.
 - Come, to our flock.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, don't fall in love with me. I'm more false than the promises a man makes while drunk. Besides, I don't like you. If you'd like to know where I live, my house is in the olive grove close by.  - Come on, sister.  - Shepherd, keep working on her.  - Come on, sister.  - Shepherdess, give him another chance. And don't be proud. The whole world could look at you, and no one would be as blind as he is, thinking you're beautiful.  - Come on, to our sheep.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSALIND, CELIA and CORIN
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN exit.

paragraphs.original:
Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might:
"Who ever loved that loved not at first sight?"
paragraphs.translated:
Dead
shepherd, now I understand what you meant when you said, "You've never loved until you've fallen in love at first sight."
shepherd

paragraphs.original: Sweet Phoebe -
paragraphs.translated: Sweet Phoebe -

paragraphs.original: Ha, what sayst thou, Silvius?
paragraphs.translated: What? Did you say something, Silvius?

paragraphs.original: Sweet Phoebe, pity me.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet Phoebe, have pity on me.

paragraphs.original: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I'm sorry for you, gentle Silvius.

paragraphs.original:
Wherever sorrow is, relief would be.
If you do sorrow at my grief in love,
By giving love your sorrow and my grief
Were both extermined.
paragraphs.translated: But if you're really sorry for me, you can cure me. If you're sorry for the grief I feel in loving you, you can love me back. Then both my grief and your sorrow will be cured.

paragraphs.original: Thou hast my love. Is not that neighborly?
paragraphs.translated: You have my friendship. Isn't that enough?

paragraphs.original: I would have you.
paragraphs.translated: I want you.

paragraphs.original:
Why, that were covetousness.
Silvius, the time was that I hated thee,
And yet it is not that I bear thee love,
But since that thou canst talk of love so well,
Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,
I will endure, and I'll employ thee too.
But do not look for further recompense
Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that's just greedy. Silvius, I used to hate you. I still don't love you, but since you're well-spoken when it comes to love, I'll keep you around and make use of you. But don't expect any more than that.

paragraphs.original:
So holy and so perfect is my love,
And I in such a poverty of grace,
That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
To glean the broken ears after the man
That the main harvest reaps. Loose now and then
A scattered smile, and that I'll live upon.
paragraphs.translated: My love for you is so pure and perfect, and I'm in such a bad way, that I'll be grateful for whatever leftover love you throw my way. Every once in a while, toss me a distracted smile, and I'll live on that.

paragraphs.original: Know'st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know the boy who was just speaking to me?

paragraphs.original:
Not very well, but I have met him oft,
And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
That the old carlot once was master of.
paragraphs.translated: Not very well, but I've met him several times. He's bought the cottage and the grounds that the old peasant used to own.

paragraphs.original:
Think not I love him, though I ask for him.
'Tis but a peevish boy - yet he talks well - 
But what care I for words? Yet words do well
When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
It is a pretty youth - not very pretty - 
But sure he's proud - and yet his pride becomes him.
He'll make a proper man. The best thing in him
Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue
Did make offense, his eye did heal it up.
He is not very tall - yet for his years he's tall.
His leg is but so-so - and yet 'tis well.
There was a pretty redness in his lip,
A little riper and more lusty red
Than that mixed in his cheek: 'twas just the difference
Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
There be some women, Silvius, had they marked him
In parcels as I did, would have gone near
To fall in love with him; but for my part
I love him not nor hate him not; and yet
I have more cause to hate him than to love him.
For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black and my hair black
And, now I am remembered, scorned at me.
I marvel why I answered not again.
But that's all one: omittance is no quittance.
I'll write to him a very taunting letter,
And thou shalt bear it. Wilt thou, Silvius?
paragraphs.translated: Don't think I'm in love with him just because I'm asking about him. He's an irritable boy, though he speaks well. But what do I care about words? And yet, words are a good thing when the man speaking them is pleasant to listen to. He's good-looking, but not too good-looking. He's awfully proud, but his pride suits him. He'll grow up to be a proper man. The best thing about him is his complexion: as fast as he offends me with words, his pretty face heals the wound. He's not very tall, but he's tall enough for his age. His legs aren't great, but they're alright. His lips were nice and red, a little more lively and passionate than the red that was in his cheeks - one was pure red and the other more pink. There are women out there, Silvius, who would have nearly fallen in love with him after inspecting him as closely as I have. But I don't love him or hate him - though I suppose I have more reason to hate him than love him. What right did he have to scold me like that? He said my eyes and my hair were black and, now that I think of it, he scorned me. I'm surprised I didn't bite back. But no matter - I'll get back at him soon enough. I'll write him a taunting letter, and you can deliver it. Will you do that for me, Silvius?

paragraphs.original: Phoebe, with all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: With all my heart, Phoebe.

paragraphs.original:
I'll write it straight.
The matter's in my head and in my heart.
I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Go with me, Silvius.
paragraphs.translated: I'll write it right now - the whole thing is pressing on my mind, and on my heart. I'll be bitter toward him, and curt. Come with me, Silvius.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES enter.

paragraphs.original: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with thee.
paragraphs.translated: Please, pretty young man, I'd like to get to know you better.

paragraphs.original: They say you are a melancholy fellow.
paragraphs.translated: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

paragraphs.original: I am so. I do love it better than laughing.
paragraphs.translated: I am. I like it better than laughing.

paragraphs.original: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.
paragraphs.translated: People who are either too serious or too silly are awful. They make themselves targets for ridicule even faster than drunks do.

paragraphs.original: Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I think it's good to be serious and keep quiet.

paragraphs.original: Why then, 'tis good to be a post.
paragraphs.translated: In that case it's good to be a post.

paragraphs.original: I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is emulation; nor the musician's, which is fantastical; nor the courtier's, which is proud; nor the soldier's, which is ambitious; nor the lawyer's, which is politic; nor the lady's, which is nice; nor the lover's, which is all these, but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not a scholar's kind of melancholy, which is all about impressing one's peers, or a musician's, which comes from his passion for his art. I don't have the proud melancholy of a courtier or the ambitious melancholy of a soldier or the calculated melancholy of a lawyer. My melancholy is not like a lady's - which is nothing more than an affectation - nor like a lover's, which combines all of these qualities. My melancholy is purely my own - a compound made from many ingredients. I'm serious because I've traveled so much. When I think about all the things I've seen, I sink into deep thoughts.

paragraphs.original: A traveler. By my faith, you have great reason to be sad. I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men's. Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.
paragraphs.translated: You're a traveler. Well then, you have good reason to be sad. I'm afraid you've sold your own land to see other men's. To have seen much but own nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

paragraphs.original: Yes, I have gained my experience.
paragraphs.translated: Not true. I gained my experience.

paragraphs.original: And your experience makes you sad. I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad -  and to travel for it, too.
paragraphs.translated: And your experience makes you sad. I'd rather have a jester to make me happy than experience to make me sad - and to travel for all that trouble, no less!

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO enters.

paragraphs.original: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: Good day and happiness to you, darling Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: Nay then, God be wi' you, an you talk in blank verse.
paragraphs.translated:
No - I'll say goodbye if you're going to talk in
blank verse.
blank verse

paragraphs.original: Farewell, Monsieur Traveler. Look you lisp and wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of your own country, be out of love with your nativity, and almost chide God for making you that countenance you are, or I will scarce think you have swam in a gondola.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, Mr. Traveler. Make sure to keep up your foreign accent, wear strange clothes, belittle all the benefits you receive from your native land and fall out of love with it, and nearly curse God for making you look like the Englishman you are, or else I'll never believe you've paddled in a gondola in a Venetian canal, as you say you have.

paragraphs.original: Exit JAQUES
paragraphs.translated: JAQUES exits.

paragraphs.original: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.
paragraphs.translated: My beautiful Rosalind, I'm only an hour late.

paragraphs.original: Break an hour's promise in love? He that will divide a minute into a thousand parts and break but a part of the thousand part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said of him that Cupid hath clapped him o' th' shoulder, but I'll warrant him heart-whole.
paragraphs.translated: You'd break a date with your beloved by a whole hour? A man who will dare to meet his lover even a thousandth part of a minute late - well, it's possible he likes her, but I doubt he really loves the woman.

paragraphs.original: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: Forgive me, darling Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. I had as lief be wooed of a snail.
paragraphs.translated: No, if you're ever late like this again, I'll refuse to see you. I'd rather be wooed by a snail.

paragraphs.original: Of a snail?
paragraphs.translated: A snail?

paragraphs.original: Ay, of a snail, for though he comes slowly, he carries his house on his head - a better jointure, I think, than you make a woman. Besides, he brings his destiny with him.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, a snail. Because even though he's slow, he carries his house on his head - a better offer than you can make a woman, I think. Besides, he brings his fate with him.

paragraphs.original: What's that?
paragraphs.translated: What fate is that?

paragraphs.original: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for. But he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.
paragraphs.translated: Why, his cuckold's horns, of course - the kind you men are always blaming on your wives. See, the snail already has its horns, which prevents nasty rumors from spreading about his wife's infidelity.

paragraphs.original: Virtue is no hornmaker, and my Rosalind is virtuous.
paragraphs.translated: A virtuous woman won't give her husband horns, and my Rosalind is definitely virtuous.

paragraphs.original: And I am your Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: And I am your Rosalind.

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena) It pleases him to call you so, but he hath a
(as Aliena)
Rosalind of a better leer than you.
paragraphs.translated:
(as Aliena) He likes calling you that, but he's got another Rosalind out there with a prettier face.
(as Aliena)

paragraphs.original: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday humor, and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, an I were your very, very Rosalind?
paragraphs.translated: Come on, woo me, woo me. I'm in a good mood now and likely to give you what you want. What would you say to me now if I really were your precious little Rosalind?

paragraphs.original: I would kiss before I spoke.
paragraphs.translated: I'd kiss you before I spoke.

paragraphs.original: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were graveled for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss. Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking - God warn us - matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.
paragraphs.translated: No, it would be better to speak first and kiss only after you've run out of things to say. When good orators finish talking, they spit; when lovers do (God help us if they ever do), they kiss.

paragraphs.original: How if the kiss be denied?
paragraphs.translated: What if she won't kiss me?

paragraphs.original: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.
paragraphs.translated: Then she's making you beg, and that gives you a whole new set of things to talk about.

paragraphs.original: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
paragraphs.translated: Who could be out of things to say if he were with the girl he loves?

paragraphs.original: Marry, that should you if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, you would be out if I were your mistress - if my chastity is worth as much as my wit.

paragraphs.original: What, of my suit?
paragraphs.translated:
Would I be out of my
suit?
suit

paragraphs.original: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit. Am not I your Rosalind?
paragraphs.translated: No, you'd still have your clothes on - but, yes, I wouldn't think much of you. Aren't I your Rosalind?

paragraphs.original: I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking of her.
paragraphs.translated: I like to pretend you are, because then it's almost like actually talking to her.

paragraphs.original: Well, in her person I say I will not have you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, on behalf of Rosalind, I'll tell you I don't want you.

paragraphs.original: Then, in mine own person I die.
paragraphs.translated: Then, on behalf of myself, I'll tell you I'll die.

paragraphs.original: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love cause. Troilus had his brains dashed out with a Grecian club, yet he did what he could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love. Leander, he would have lived many a fair year though Hero had turned nun if it had not been for a hot midsummer night, for, good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont and, being taken with the cramp, was drowned; and the foolish chroniclers of that age found it was Hero of Sestos. But these are all lies. Men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not for love.
paragraphs.translated:
No, you won't die yourself, but only by proxy. This world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time not one man has ever actually died from love.
Troilus may have wanted to die from love, and he's now considered one of the great, tragic love heroes, but, in fact, a Greek with a club beat his brains out. It had nothing to do with love. Leander would have lived many more years if it hadn't been for a particularly hot summer night, when he went swimming in the Hellespont, got a cramp, and drowned. The foolish poets of the time insisted he died for love, but they're lying. All the love stories are lies. Men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not because of love.
Troilus

paragraphs.original: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind, for I protest her frown might kill me.
paragraphs.translated: I hope Rosalind doesn't feel as you do. Her frown alone would kill me.

paragraphs.original: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come; now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition, and ask me what you will, I will grant it.
paragraphs.translated: No, her frown wouldn't kill a fly. But come on, now I'll play your Rosalind, and in a more friendly state of mind. Whatever you ask for, I'll give.

paragraphs.original: Then love me, Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: Then love me, Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.
paragraphs.translated: Okay, I will - on Fridays and Saturdays, and the rest.

paragraphs.original: And wilt thou have me?
paragraphs.translated: And will you have me?

paragraphs.original: Ay, and twenty such.
paragraphs.translated: Sure, and twenty others just like you.

paragraphs.original: What sayest thou?
paragraphs.translated: What's that?

paragraphs.original: Are you not good?
paragraphs.translated: Well, aren't you a good man?

paragraphs.original: I hope so.
paragraphs.translated: I hope so.

paragraphs.original: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing? -  Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us. - Give me your hand, Orlando. - What do you say, sister?
paragraphs.translated: And can a person ever have too much of a good thing? - Come on, sister, you can be the priest and marry us. - Give me your hand, Orlando. - What do you say, sister?

paragraphs.original: Pray thee, marry us.
paragraphs.translated: Please, marry us.

paragraphs.original: I cannot say the words.
paragraphs.translated:
I can't say the
words.
words

paragraphs.original: You must begin "Will you, Orlando - "
paragraphs.translated: You just have to say, "Do you, Orlando - "

paragraphs.original: Go to. - Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, stop it. - Do you, Orlando, take Rosalind to be your lawfully wedded wife?

paragraphs.original: I will.
paragraphs.translated: I do.

paragraphs.original: Ay, but when?
paragraphs.translated: Okay, but when?

paragraphs.original: Why, now, as fast as she can marry us.
paragraphs.translated: Right now; as fast as she can say the vows.

paragraphs.original: Then you must say "I take thee, Rosalind, for wife."
paragraphs.translated: Then you have to say, "I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife."

paragraphs.original: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.
paragraphs.translated: I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife.

paragraphs.original: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband. There's a girl goes before the priest, and certainly a woman's thought runs before her actions.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe I should ask you what right you have to take me, but I'll take you, Orlando, to be my husband. Look, I've sped ahead of the priest and answered the question before he even asked. A woman's thoughts are always running ahead of her actions.

paragraphs.original: So do all thoughts. They are winged.
paragraphs.translated: So do all thoughts. They have wings.

paragraphs.original: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.
paragraphs.translated: Now tell me how long you intend to keep her.

paragraphs.original: Forever and a day.
paragraphs.translated: Forever and a day.

paragraphs.original: Say "a day" without the "ever." No, no, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed. Maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock- pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more newfangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. I will weep for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry. I will laugh like a hyena, and that when thou art inclined to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: You might as well just say for "a day," and forget the "ever" part. No, Orlando, men are like April when they're wooing a girl - young, and passionate - but like December once they're married and their passions have cooled. Women are as sweet and temperate as springtime when they're single, but the climate changes once they're married. I'll be more jealous of you than a wild rooster over his hen; more noisy than a parrot chattering about the rain; more fond of new things than an ape; more giddy about getting what I want than a monkey. I'll cry at nothing, and I'll always do it when you're in a good mood. And when you want to go to sleep, I'll be up laughing like a hyena.

paragraphs.original: But will my Rosalind do so?
paragraphs.translated: But will my Rosalind do this, too?

paragraphs.original: By my life, she will do as I do.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, she'll act just like me.

paragraphs.original: Oh, but she is wise.
paragraphs.translated: But she is wise.

paragraphs.original: Or else she could not have the wit to do this. The wiser, the waywarder. Make the doors upon a woman's wit, and it will out at the casement. Shut that, and 'twill out at the keyhole. Stop that, 'twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.
paragraphs.translated: Right. If she weren't wise, she wouldn't be smart enough to behave badly. The wiser the woman, the wilder. If you close the doors on a woman's wit, it'll fly out the window. If you shut the windows, it will pour out the keyhole. If you stop up the keyhole, it will escape from the chimney along with the smoke.

paragraphs.original: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say "Wit, whither wilt?"
paragraphs.translated: A man with a wife like that might ask, "Hey, wandering wit, where are you off to?"

paragraphs.original: Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your wife's wit going to your neighbor's bed.
paragraphs.translated: Nah, better save the questions for when you find her in your neighbor's bed.

paragraphs.original: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?
paragraphs.translated:
And what wit could excuse that?
that

paragraphs.original: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue. Oh, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband's occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.
paragraphs.translated: She'll say she was at the neighbor's looking for you. You'll never find her without an answer unless you find her without a tongue. A woman who doesn't know how to make her own indiscretions look like her husband's fault is hardly a woman. And she's hardly fit to be a mother - her child will turn out to be a fool.

paragraphs.original: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.
paragraphs.translated: Rosalind, I have to leave you for two hours.

paragraphs.original: Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, no! Darling, I can't live without you for two hours.

paragraphs.original: I must attend the duke at dinner. By two o'clock I will be with thee again.
paragraphs.translated: I must join the duke for lunch. I'll be back here with you by two o'clock.

paragraphs.original: Ay, go your ways, go your ways. I knew what you would prove. My friends told me as much, and I thought no less. That flattering tongue of yours won me. 'Tis but one cast away, and so, come, death. Two o'clock is your hour?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, go, leave me. I knew you'd turn out this way. My friends told me as much, and I knew it, too. But I was won over by your flattering words. I'm just another girl whom you've cast aside. So, take me, death! You'll be back at two o'clock?

paragraphs.original: Ay, sweet Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sweet Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot of your promise or come one minute behind your hour, I will think you the most pathetical break-promise and the most hollow lover and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind that may be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful. Therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, truly, in God's name, and by all those little girly oaths that don't actually have any power, if you break even a little bit of your promise, or if you come even a minute after two o'clock, I'll think you the most pathetic promise breaker, the most lying lover, and the most unworthy partner for Rosalind that could be found anywhere. So beware of my contempt, and keep your promise.

paragraphs.original:
With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind.
So, adieu.
paragraphs.translated: I'll keep my promise just as if you really were Rosalind. So, goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Well, time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let time try. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: Well, time is the old judge that tries your kind of criminal. Time will tell what kind of a man you are. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit ORLANDO
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO exits.

paragraphs.original: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate. We must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
paragraphs.translated: You have absolutely abused our sex in this love talk of yours. We should rip off your man's clothing and show the world the woman who has represented her own kind so badly.

paragraphs.original: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love. But it cannot be sounded; my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the Bay of Portugal.
paragraphs.translated: Oh cousin, cousin, cousin, my sweet little cousin, I wish you knew how deep in love I am. The bottom of my love is so deep it can't be reached. It's as deep as the bay of Portugal.

paragraphs.original: Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.
paragraphs.translated: Or it's bottomless, at least: pour affection in one end, and it runs out the other.

paragraphs.original: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceived of spleen, and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses everyone's eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love. I'll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando. I'll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.
paragraphs.translated: Cupid - that blind bastard son of Venus, conceived from a thought and anger, born from insanity, that blind, naughty boy who makes everyone else go blind just because he can't see himself - let Cupid judge how deep my love runs. I'm telling you, Aliena, I can't stand being apart from Orlando. I'm going to find some shade and sigh until he returns.

paragraphs.original: And I'll sleep.
paragraphs.translated: And I'm going to sleep.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter JAQUES and LORDS, like foresters
paragraphs.translated: JAQUES enters with LORDS, dressed like foresters.

paragraphs.original: Which is he that killed the deer?
paragraphs.translated: Which one of you killed the deer?

paragraphs.original: Sir, it was I.
paragraphs.translated: It was me, sir.

paragraphs.original: Let's present him to the duke like a Roman conqueror. And it would do well to set the deer's horns upon his head for a branch of victory. - Have you no song, forester, for this purpose?
paragraphs.translated: Let's bring this man to the duke, like a triumphant Roman conqueror. Put the deer's horns on his head, like a victory branch. Do you have a song, forester, for this occasion?

paragraphs.original: Yes, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original: Sing it. 'Tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise enough.
paragraphs.translated: Then sing it. It doesn't matter if it's in tune so long as it's loud enough.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
What shall he have that killed the deer?
What shall he have that killed the deer?
His leather skin and horns to wear.
His leather skin and horns to wear.
Then sing him home.
Then sing him home.
(The rest shall bear this burden.)
(The rest shall bear this burden.)
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn.
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn.
It was a crest ere thou wast born.
It was a crest ere thou wast born.
Thy father's father wore it,
Thy father's father wore it,
And thy father bore it.
And thy father bore it.
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
What should we give to the man who killed this deer?
What should we give to the man who killed this deer?
Give him the hide and the horns to wear.
Give him the hide and the horns to wear.
Then sing this song to send him home
Then sing this song to send him home
(The other LORDS pick up the deer)
(The other
pick up the deer)
Don't be ashamed to wear the horns.
Don't be ashamed to wear the horns.
They've been worn since before you were born.
They've been worn since before you were born.
Your father's father wore it,
Your father's father wore it,
And your father endured it.
And your father endured it.
The horn, the horn, the lustful horn
The horn, the horn, the lustful horn
Is not to be laughed at or scorned.
Is not to be laughed at or scorned.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND and CELIA enter.

paragraphs.original: How say you now? Is it not past two o'clock? And here much Orlando.
paragraphs.translated: What do you say now? Isn't it past two o'clock? And I see a lot of Orlando here.

paragraphs.original: I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain he hath ta'en his bow and arrows and is gone forth to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, he's taken his bow and arrows and, with a pure love and a worried brain, has gone to take a nap.

paragraphs.original: Enter SILVIUS
paragraphs.translated: SILVIUS enters.

paragraphs.original: Look who comes here.
paragraphs.translated: Look who's coming.

paragraphs.original:
(to ROSALIND) My errand is to you, fair youth.
(to
)
My gentle Phoebe did bid me give you this.
I know not the contents, but as I guess
By the stern brow and waspish action
Which she did use as she was writing of it,
It bears an angry tenor. Pardon me.
I am but as a guiltless messenger.
(Gives the letter)
(Gives the letter)

(Examines the letter) (as Ganymede) Patience herself would startle at this letter
(Examines the letter) (as Ganymede)
And play the swaggerer. Bear this, bear all.
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners.
She calls me proud, and that she could not love me
Were man as rare as phoenix. 'Od's my will,
Her love is not the hare that I do hunt.
Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,
This is a letter of your own device.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading the letter as Ganymede) Patience herself would be shocked by this letter and become feisty. If I can take this, I can take anything. She says I'm not handsome and have no manners. She says I'm arrogant and that she couldn't love me even if men were as rare as the mythical phoenix. Honestly! I'm not hunting after her love. Why would she write this way to me? Tell the truth, shepherd: you wrote this letter.
(reading the letter as Ganymede)

paragraphs.original:
No, I protest, I know not the contents.
Phoebe did write it.
paragraphs.translated: No, I swear, I don't even know what's in it. Phoebe wrote it.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, you are a fool,
And turned into the extremity of love.
I saw her hand. She has a leathern hand,
A freestone-colored hand. I verily did think
That her old gloves were on, but 'twas her hands.
She has a huswife's hand - but that's no matter.
I say she never did invent this letter.
This is a man's invention, and his hand.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you're a fool, and driven to extreme measures by love. I saw her hands: they were as rough as leather and just as brown; I thought she was wearing old gloves, but they were, in fact, her hands. These are the hands of a hard-working housewife, but that's not the point. The point is that she didn't write this letter. These are a man's words, and his handwriting.

paragraphs.original: Sure it is hers.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, it's hers.

paragraphs.original:
Why, 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style,
A style for challengers. Why, she defies me
Like Turk to Christian. Women's gentle brain
Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention,
Such Ethiop words, blacker in their effect
Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?
paragraphs.translated: Well, it's written in a boisterous and rude style - someone is up for a fight. Why, she challenges me like a Muslim would challenge a Christian. No, a woman's gentle brain could never have come up with such crude expressions and even harsher meanings. Do you want to hear what she says?

paragraphs.original:
So please you, for I never heard it yet,
Yet heard too much of Phoebe's cruelty.
paragraphs.translated: If you want to read it, as I haven't heard it yet, though I've heard too much of Phoebe's cruelty.

paragraphs.original:
She Phoebes me. Mark how the tyrant writes.
(reads) Art thou god to shepherd turned,
(reads)
That a maiden's heart hath burned?
Can a woman rail thus?
paragraphs.translated:
She's Phoebe-ing me. Listen to what the tyrant says. (reading) "Are you a god disguised as a shepherd, that you know so expertly how to burn my heart?" Now, honestly, would a woman rant like this?
(reading)

paragraphs.original: Call you this railing?
paragraphs.translated: You call that ranting?

paragraphs.original:
(reads)
(reads)
Why, thy godhead laid apart,
Warr'st thou with a woman's heart?
Did you ever hear such railing?
Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
That could do no vengeance to me.
Meaning me a beast.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading) "Why have you set aside your divine nature just to battle with a woman's affections?" Did you ever hear such ranting? (reading) "When other men have wooed me, they didn't hurt me." In other words, she thinks I'm not a man, but an animal.
(reading)
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
If the scorn of your bright eyne
Have power to raise such love in mine,
Alack, in me what strange effect
Would they work in mild aspect?
Whiles you chid me, I did love.
How then might your prayers move?
He that brings this love to thee
Little knows this love in me,
And by him seal up thy mind
Whether that thy youth and kind
Will the faithful offer take
Of me, and all that I can make,
Or else by him my love deny,
And then I'll study how to die.
paragraphs.translated:
(reading) "If the scorn in your bright eyes can make me fall so deeply in love, can you imagine what power they might have if they looked at me more kindly? While you sneered at me, I loved you. Consider what effect kind prayers might have. The man that brings you this letter doesn't know how I feel about you. Send me your answer via him. Tell me via him whether you will accept my faithful offer of myself and all that I can do. Or tell him you will deny my love, in which case I'll figure out how to die."
(reading)

paragraphs.original: Call you this chiding?
paragraphs.translated: You call this sneering?

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena) Alas, poor shepherd.
(as Aliena)
paragraphs.translated:
(as Aliena) Oh, you poor shepherd!
(as Aliena)

paragraphs.original: Do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity. - Wilt thou love such a woman? What, to make thee an instrument and play false strains upon thee? Not to be endured. Well, go your way to her, for I see love hath made thee a tame snake, and say this to her: that if she love me, I charge her to love thee; if she will not, I will never have her unless thou entreat for her. If you be a true lover, hence and not a word, for here comes more company.
Exit SILVIUS
paragraphs.translated: SILVIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter OLIVER
paragraphs.translated: OLIVER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow, fair ones. Pray you, if you know,
Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
A sheepcote fenced about with olive trees?
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, pretty ones. Tell me, if you know: where in this forest is there a shepherd's cottage surrounded by olive trees?

paragraphs.original:
(as Aliena)
(as Aliena)
West of this place, down in the neighbor bottom,
The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
Left on your right hand brings you to the place.
But at this hour the house doth keep itself.
There's none within.
paragraphs.translated: West of here, in the valley next to us. Passing by on your right, there is a row of willows. Follow them straight to the cottage. But right now, the house is keeping to itself -  there's no one home.

paragraphs.original:
If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then should I know you by description.
Such garments, and such years. "The boy is fair,
Of female favor, and bestows himself
Like a ripe sister; the woman low
And browner than her brother." Are not you
The owner of the house I did inquire for?
paragraphs.translated: I think I recognize you from a description I was given of your clothing and age: "The boy is pretty and feminine, and carries himself like a blooming young woman. The woman is short, with a darker complexion than her brother." Aren't you the owners of the house I was just asking about?

paragraphs.original: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.
paragraphs.translated: Since you asked, I suppose it's not bragging to say that we are.

paragraphs.original:
Orlando doth commend him to you both,
And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?
paragraphs.translated: Orlando sends his regards to you both, and he sends this bloody handkerchief to the boy he calls "his Rosalind." Is that you?

paragraphs.original:
(as Ganymede) I am. What must we understand by this?
(as Ganymede)
paragraphs.translated: It is. What does this mean?

paragraphs.original:
Some of my shame, if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where
This handkercher was stained.
paragraphs.translated: It's a story that involves some shame on my part. It's about who I am, and how, why, and where this handkerchief was stained.

paragraphs.original: I pray you, tell it.
paragraphs.translated: Please, tell us.

paragraphs.original:
When last the young Orlando parted from you,
He left a promise to return again
Within an hour, and pacing through the forest,
Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
Lo, what befell. He threw his eye aside - 
And mark what object did present itself:
Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age
And high top bald with dry antiquity,
A wretched, ragged man, o'ergrown with hair,
Lay sleeping on his back. About his neck
A green and gilded snake had wreathed itself,
Who with her head, nimble in threats, approached
The opening of his mouth. But suddenly,
Seeing Orlando, it unlinked itself
And, with indented glides, did slip away
Into a bush, under which bush's shade
A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch
When that the sleeping man should stir - for 'tis
The royal disposition of that beast
To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead.
This seen, Orlando did approach the man
And found it was his brother, his elder brother.
paragraphs.translated: When young Orlando left you last, he promised to return within an hour. He was pacing through the forest, thinking bittersweet thoughts of love, and listen what happened! He looked to the side, and pay attention to what he saw then: under an oak tree - whose lower branches were mossy with age and top branches ancient and brittle - he saw a wretched beggar, with overgrown hair and beard, asleep on his back. A green and gold snake had wound itself around this man's neck and was slowly making its way toward the man's mouth. However, when it saw Orlando, it unwound itself and slunk away into a bush. But there happened to be a lioness crouching under that bush. Her cubs had nursed from her until she was dry, so she was ravenously hungry, and she was lying with her head on the ground, watching the man as cats do and waiting to see if he would wake up - a lion won't prey on anything that seems dead. Seeing the lioness, Orlando approached the sleeping man. He discovered that the man was his older brother.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, I have heard him speak of that same brother,
And he did render him the most unnatural
That lived amongst men.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I've heard him talk about that brother, and he described him as the most inhumane man alive.

paragraphs.original:
And well he might so do,
For well I know he was unnatural.
paragraphs.translated: And he was right. I know exactly how inhumane he was.

paragraphs.original:
But to Orlando: did he leave him there,
Food to the sucked and hungry lioness?
paragraphs.translated: But, back to Orlando, did he leave his brother there, to be food for the hungry mother-lioness?

paragraphs.original:
Twice did he turn his back and purposed so,
But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
And nature, stronger than his just occasion,
Made him give battle to the lioness,
Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling,
From miserable slumber I awaked.
paragraphs.translated: He turned away twice and almost left him there. But his kindness was nobler than even his desire for revenge, his natural goodness was stronger than his need to give his brother what he deserved. He fought the lioness and quickly defeated her. I woke from my miserable sleep when I heard the noise of their struggle.

paragraphs.original: Are you his brother?
paragraphs.translated: Are you his brother?

paragraphs.original: Was 't you he rescued?
paragraphs.translated: Was it you that he rescued?

paragraphs.original: Was 't you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
paragraphs.translated: Was it you that was always plotting to kill him?

paragraphs.original:
'Twas I, but 'tis not I. I do not shame
To tell you what I was, since my conversion
So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.
paragraphs.translated: That was me, but it's not me -  I'm not ashamed to tell you what I once was, since I'm so happy to have since converted.

paragraphs.original: But for the bloody napkin?
paragraphs.translated: But what about the bloody handkerchief?

paragraphs.original:
By and by.
When from the first to last betwixt us two
Tears our recountments had most kindly bathed - 
As how I came into that desert place - 
In brief, he led me to the gentle duke,
Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
Committing me unto my brother's love,
Who led me instantly unto his cave,
There stripped himself, and here upon his arm
The lioness had torn some flesh away,
Which all this while had bled. And now he fainted,
And cried in fainting upon Rosalind.
Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound,
And after some small space, being strong at heart,
paragraphs.translated: I'll get there. When we had told each other our entire stories and cried, and I'd told him how I'd ended up in in the forest - well, he brought me to the duke, who gave me fresh clothing and hospitality, and put me in my brother's care. My brother immediately took me to his cave, where he took off his clothing and there on his arm was a wound where the lioness had attacked him, ripping off some of his flesh. The wound had been bleeding the entire time. So, now he fainted, and as he fainted, he called out, "Rosalind!" Quickly, I resuscitated him and bound up his wound. After a brief time - as he is a strong, brave man -

paragraphs.original:
He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
To tell this story, that you might excuse
His broken promise, and to give this napkin
Dyed in his blood unto the shepherd youth
That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: he sent me out to find you, even though I'm a stranger to you. He wanted me to tell you this story and beg your forgiveness for his having broken his promise. He wanted me to give this handkerchief, soaked in his blood, to the boy that he jokingly calls his Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: ROSALIND swoons
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND faints.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, Ganymede, sweet Ganymede?
paragraphs.translated: Oh no! Ganymede! Ganymede, sweetheart?

paragraphs.original: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
paragraphs.translated: Many people faint when they see blood.

paragraphs.original: There is more in it. - Cousin Ganymede.
paragraphs.translated: There's more to it than that. - Ganymede!

paragraphs.original: Look, he recovers.
paragraphs.translated: Look, he's recovering.

paragraphs.original: I would I were at home.
paragraphs.translated: I want to go home.

paragraphs.original:
We'll lead you thither.
 - I pray you, will you take him by the arm?
paragraphs.translated: We'll take you there. Please, will you take his arm?

paragraphs.original: Be of good cheer, youth. You a man? You lack a man's heart.
paragraphs.translated: Buck up, boy! You're a man? You don't have a man's courage.

paragraphs.original: I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well-counterfeited. I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho.
paragraphs.translated: It's true, I confess. Oh, sir, someone would think I was a good fake. Please tell your brother what a convincing show I put on. Whoo-hoo!

paragraphs.original: This was not counterfeit. There is too great testimony in your complexion that it was a passion of earnest.
paragraphs.translated: That was no show. Your cheeks are too flushed for me to believe that was a fake faint.

paragraphs.original: Counterfeit, I assure you.
paragraphs.translated: Fake, I'm telling you.

paragraphs.original: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, be brave and pretend to be a man.

paragraphs.original: So I do. But i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I'm doing. But honestly, I should have been a woman.

paragraphs.original: Come, you look paler and paler. Pray you, draw homewards. - Good sir, go with us.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you keep getting paler. Please, let's go home. Sir, please come with us.

paragraphs.original:
That will I, for I must bear answer back
How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do that, because I have to tell my brother how you forgave him, Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: I shall devise something. But I pray you commend my counterfeiting to him. Will you go?
paragraphs.translated: I'll think of something. But please, tell him how well I faked a faint. Will you come with us?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
paragraphs.translated: TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY enter.

paragraphs.original: We shall find a time, Audrey. Patience, gentle Audrey.
paragraphs.translated: We'll get married at some point, Audrey. Be patient.

paragraphs.original: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old gentleman's saying.
paragraphs.translated: Really, the priest was good enough, no matter what that old guy said.

paragraphs.original: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext. But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you.
paragraphs.translated: No, he was wicked and vile. But Audrey, there's a boy in the forest who claims you're his girl.

paragraphs.original: Ay, I know who 'tis. He hath no interest in me in the world.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I know who you're talking about, but he has no claim on me.

paragraphs.original: Enter WILLIAM
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAM enters.

paragraphs.original: Here comes the man you mean.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the man himself.

paragraphs.original: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown. By my troth, we that have good wits have much to answer for. We shall be flouting. We cannot hold.
paragraphs.translated: It warms my heart to encounter such a country bumpkin. Truly, we witty men can't hold our tongues. We have to mess with the likes of him, we just can't help it.

paragraphs.original: Good ev'n, Audrey.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening, Audrey.

paragraphs.original: God gi' good ev'n, William.
paragraphs.translated: Good evening, William.

paragraphs.original: And good ev'n to you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: And good evening to you, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Good ev'n, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy head.
Nay, prithee, be covered. How old are you, friend?
paragraphs.translated: Good evening to you, good friend. No, no, put your hat back on, put it back on. No, please, keep your head covered. How old are you, friend?

paragraphs.original: Five-and-twenty, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Twenty-five, sir.

paragraphs.original: A ripe age. Is thy name William?
paragraphs.translated: A mature age. Is your name William?

paragraphs.original: William, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it's William, sir.

paragraphs.original: A fair name. Wast born i' th' forest here?
paragraphs.translated: A good name. Were you born here in the forest?

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir, I thank God.
paragraphs.translated: Yes sir, thank God.

paragraphs.original: "Thank God." A good answer. Art rich?
paragraphs.translated: "Thank God" - that's a good answer. Are you rich?

paragraphs.original: 'Faith, sir, so-so.
paragraphs.translated: Well, so-so.

paragraphs.original: "So-so" is good, very good, very excellent good. And yet it is not: it is but so-so. Art thou wise?
paragraphs.translated: "So-so" is good, very good, an excellent answer. And then again, it's not so good, but only so-so. Are you wise?

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.
paragraphs.translated: Yes sir, I'm fairly witty.

paragraphs.original: Why, thou sayst well. I do now remember a saying: "The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool." The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a grape, would open his lips when he put it into his mouth, meaning thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open. You do love this maid?
paragraphs.translated:
Well, that's a fine answer. I seem to remember a saying: "Only a fool thinks he's wise; the
wise man knows that he is, in fact, a fool." When one self-described philosopher wanted to eat grapes, he opened his lips when they entered his mouth, thereby making the theoretical point that grapes were made to be eaten, and lips to open. Do you love this girl?
wise man

paragraphs.original: I do, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I do, sir.

paragraphs.original: Give me your hand. Art thou learned?
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand. Are you educated?

paragraphs.original: No, sir.
paragraphs.translated: No, sir.

paragraphs.original: Then learn this of me: to have is to have. For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other. For all your writers do consent that ipse is "he." Now, you are not ipse, for I am he.
paragraphs.translated:
Then learn this from me: if you have something, you have it. Everyone knows that when you pour a drink out of a cup and into a glass, the cup becomes empty. And all the authorities know that ipse is Latin for "he." You are no longer ipse, because I am he.
ipse
ipse

paragraphs.original: Which he, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Which he, sir?

paragraphs.original: He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you clown, abandon - which is, in the vulgar, "leave" - the society - which in the boorish is "company" - of this female - which in the common is "woman"; which together is, abandon the society of this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into death, thy liberty into bondage. I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel. I will bandy with thee in faction. I will o'errun thee with policy. I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways. Therefore tremble and depart.
paragraphs.translated: Why, the he that will marry this woman. Therefore, idiot, abandon (or, in common language, "leave") the society (which in the boorish tongue is "company") of this female - maybe you'll get it if I say "woman," instead. Say it all at once, now: abandon the society of this female, or, simpleton, you'll perish. Let me put it in a way you'll understand: you'll die. Or, rather, I'll kill you, or I'll do away with you, or I'll turn your life into death and your freedom into captivity. I'll poison you, or beat you with a club, or stab you with a sword. I'll bandy you about and overwhelm you with my cleverness. I will, in other words, kill you in three hundred and fifty ways. Therefore, tremble with fear and leave.

paragraphs.original: Do, good William.
paragraphs.translated: Do what he says, William.

paragraphs.original: God rest you merry, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CORIN
paragraphs.translated: CORIN enters.

paragraphs.original: Our master and mistress seeks you. Come away, away.
paragraphs.translated: Our master and mistress are looking for you. Let's go.

paragraphs.original: Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey. - I attend, I attend.
paragraphs.translated: Hurry up, Audrey, hurry. - I'm coming, I'm coming.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER
paragraphs.translated: ORLANDO and OLIVER enter.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her? That, but seeing, you should love her? And loving, woo? And wooing, she should grant? And will you persever to enjoy her?
paragraphs.translated: Is it really possible that you could like her right after meeting her? And fall in love with her after merely seeing her? And as soon as you fall in love, with her, woo her? And as soon as you woo her, have her accept? And do you really mean to marry her?

paragraphs.original: Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor her sudden consenting, but say with me "I love Aliena"; say with her that she loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. It shall be to your good, for my father's house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland's will I estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.
paragraphs.translated: Don't question the foolish haste of it all - or her poverty or our short time together or the abruptness of my courtship or the abruptness of her consent - but say with me, "I love Aliena." And say with me that she loves me. Agree to this match, so we can enjoy each other. It will be to your advantage, because I'll leave our father's house and all his property to you, while I live and die a shepherd here in the forest.

paragraphs.original:
You have my consent. Let your wedding be tomorrow.
Thither will I invite the duke and all's contented followers.
Go you and prepare Aliena, for look you, here comes my
Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: You have my consent. You can be married tomorrow if you want. I'll invite the duke and all of his followers. Go get Aliena ready - because, look, here comes my Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND enters.

paragraphs.original:
(as Ganymede) God save you, brother.
(as Ganymede)
paragraphs.translated: Hello, brother.

paragraphs.original: And you, fair sister.
paragraphs.translated: And hello to you, fair sister.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: O my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, darling Orlando, it's so hard to see you wearing your heart in a sling.

paragraphs.original: It is my arm.
paragraphs.translated: Actually, it's my arm.

paragraphs.original: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.
paragraphs.translated: I thought your heart had been wounded by a lion's claws.

paragraphs.original: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.
paragraphs.translated:
My heart has been wounded, but by a lady, not a lion.
has

paragraphs.original: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon when he showed me your handkercher?
paragraphs.translated: Did your brother tell you how well I pretended to faint when he showed me the handkerchief?

paragraphs.original: Ay, and greater wonders than that.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and he told me some things that were even more amazing.

paragraphs.original: Oh, I know where you are. Nay, 'tis true. There was never anything so sudden but the fight of two rams and Caesar's thrasonical brag of "I came, saw, and overcame." For your brother and my sister no sooner met but they looked, no sooner looked but they loved, no sooner loved but they sighed, no sooner sighed but they asked one another the reason, no sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy; and in these degrees have they made a pair of stairs to marriage, which they will climb incontinent, or else be incontinent before marriage. They are in the very wrath of love, and they will together. Clubs cannot part them.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I know what you're talking about. It's true: it was as sudden as two rams rushing at each other, and as quick as Julius Caesar's "I came, I saw, I conquered."
