Your brother and my sister had no sooner met than they gave each other a good once over; they had no sooner looked at each other than they fell in love; no sooner fell in love than they sighed; no sooner sighed than they asked each other why they had sighed; no sooner answered than they sought a solution. And in this way, degree by degree, they've built a staircase toward marriage. And they had better climb those stairs immediately, or else they'll end up in bed before they ought to. They're in the heat of passion; they simply have to be together. You couldn't beat the two of them apart.

paragraphs.original: They shall be married tomorrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial. But Oh, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man's eyes. By so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.
paragraphs.translated: They'll be married tomorrow, and I'll invite the duke to the ceremony. But, oh, it makes me bitter to look at happiness through another man's eyes. Tomorrow I'll be at the depths of my misery thinking about the happiness my brother has achieved, in having what he wished for.

paragraphs.original: Why, then, tomorrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?
paragraphs.translated: Well then, can't I act as Rosalind for you tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: I can live no longer by thinking.
paragraphs.translated: I can't live by pretending anymore.

paragraphs.original: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking. Know of me then - for now I speak to some purpose - that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit. I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are. Neither do I labor for a greater esteem than may in some little measure draw a belief from you to do yourself good, and not to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things. I have, since I was three year old, conversed with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable. If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her. I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.
paragraphs.translated: I won't exhaust you anymore with idle chitchat. You should know that I think you're a smart man. I really mean it. I'm not telling you this so you'll think well of me (who wouldn't think well of someone who thought well of him, after all?) And I'm not trying to enhance my own reputation, but only to do you good. Believe me, then, that I have special powers. Since I was three years old, I've been in contact with a powerful but virtuous magician - no black magic here. If you love Rosalind as much as you say you do, you will marry her when your brother marries Aliena. I know where she is and, if you don't mind, I will set her before you tomorrow, whole and unharmed.

paragraphs.original: Speak'st thou in sober meanings?
paragraphs.translated: Are you serious?

paragraphs.original: By my life I do, which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician. Therefore put you in your best array, bid your friends; for if you will be married tomorrow, you shall, and to Rosalind, if you will.
paragraphs.translated: I swear on my life, which I take pretty seriously, even if I am a magician. So put on your best clothes and tell your friends to come. Because if you want to be married tomorrow, you will, and if you want to be married to Rosalind, you will.

paragraphs.original: Enter SILVIUS and PHOEBE
paragraphs.translated: SILVIUS and PHOEBE enter.

paragraphs.original: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here comes someone who loves me, along with someone who loves her.

paragraphs.original:
Youth, you have done me much ungentleness
To show the letter that I writ to you.
paragraphs.translated: Young man, it was very rude of you to show him the letter I wrote you.

paragraphs.original:
I care not if I have. It is my study
To seem despiteful and ungentle to you.
You are there followed by a faithful shepherd.
Look upon him, love him; he worships you.
paragraphs.translated: I don't care. I'm being contemptuous and cruel toward you on purpose. A faithful shepherd worships you. Why don't you pay attention to him? Why don't you love him? He adores you.

paragraphs.original: Good shepherd, tell this youth what 'tis to love.
paragraphs.translated: Silvius, tell this youth what it means to be in love.

paragraphs.original:
It is to be all made of sighs and tears,
And so am I for Phoebe.
paragraphs.translated: It means being full of sighs and tears, like I am for Phoebe.

paragraphs.original: And I for Ganymede.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for Ganymede.

paragraphs.original: And I for Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: And I for no woman.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for no woman.

paragraphs.original:
It is to be all made of faith and service,
And so am I for Phoebe.
paragraphs.translated: It means being faithful and ready to serve, just like I am for Phoebe.

paragraphs.original: And I for Ganymede.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for Ganymede.

paragraphs.original: And I for Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: And I for no woman.
paragraphs.translated: And like I am for no woman.

paragraphs.original:
It is to be all made of fantasy,
All made of passion and all made of wishes,
All adoration, duty, and observance,
All humbleness, all patience and impatience,
All purity, all trial, all observance,
And so am I for Phoebe.
paragraphs.translated: It means being filled with fantasy; with passion and wishes; with adoration, loyalty, and devotion. It means being humble, being patient, being impatient, being pure, being put-upon, being obedient. Just as I am for Phoebe.

paragraphs.original: And so am I for Ganymede.
paragraphs.translated: And I for Ganymede.

paragraphs.original: And so am I for Rosalind.
paragraphs.translated: And I for Rosalind.

paragraphs.original: And so am I for no woman.
paragraphs.translated: And I for no woman.

paragraphs.original: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
paragraphs.translated: Since you know all this is true, why do you blame me for loving you?

paragraphs.original: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
paragraphs.translated: And why do you blame me for loving you?

paragraphs.original: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
paragraphs.translated: And why do you blame me for loving you?

paragraphs.original: Why do you speak, too, "Why blame you me to love you?"?
paragraphs.translated: Who are you talking to?

paragraphs.original: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.
paragraphs.translated: I'm saying it to the girl who isn't here and doesn't hear me.

paragraphs.original: I'll not fail, if I live.
paragraphs.translated: As long as I'm alive, I'll be here.

paragraphs.original: Nor I.
paragraphs.translated: Me too.

paragraphs.original: Nor I.
paragraphs.translated: Me too.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY.
paragraphs.translated: TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY enter.

paragraphs.original: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey. Tomorrow will we be married.
paragraphs.translated: Tomorrow is the happy day, Audrey. We'll be married tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: I do desire it with all my heart, and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world.
paragraphs.translated: I can't wait. I hope it doesn't make me unchaste that I really want to be a married woman.

paragraphs.original: Enter two PAGES
paragraphs.translated: Two PAGES enter.

paragraphs.original: Here comes two of the banished duke's pages.
paragraphs.translated: Here come two of Duke Senior's pages.

paragraphs.original: Well met, honest gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: Good afternoon, good gentleman.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.
paragraphs.translated: It really is good to see you. Come, sit, sit, and sing me a song.

paragraphs.original: We are for you. Sit i' th' middle.
paragraphs.translated: Sounds good to us. Sit between us.

paragraphs.original: Shall we clap into 't roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?
paragraphs.translated: Should we just get down to it? Should we skip all that hacking and spitting and saying that we're hoarse, which only makes clear what lousy singers we are?

paragraphs.original: I' faith, i' faith, and both in a tune like two gypsies on a horse.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, yes, and let's sing in unison, like two gypsies riding on a single horse.

paragraphs.original: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untunable.
paragraphs.translated: Really, young men, though it wasn't a very hard song to get right, the music was still all out of tune.

paragraphs.original: You are deceived, sir. We kept time. We lost not our time.
paragraphs.translated:
No, sir, you're wrong; we kept the
song's time, we didn't lose any.
song's

paragraphs.original: By my troth, yes. I count it but time lost to hear such a foolish song. God be wi' you, and God mend your voices. -  Come, Audrey.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes you did - I lost time listening to your foolish song. God be with you, and I hope He fixes your voices! Come on, Audrey.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA
paragraphs.translated: DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promisèd?
paragraphs.translated: Orlando, do you really believe that this boy can do everything he's promised?

paragraphs.original:
I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not,
As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.
paragraphs.translated: Sometimes I do and sometimes I don't. I'm afraid of hoping, but I hope anyway.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHOEBE
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHOEBE enter.

paragraphs.original:
(as Ganymede) Patience once more whiles our compact is urged.
(as Ganymede)
(to DUKE SENIOR ) You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,
(to
)
You will bestow her on Orlando here?
paragraphs.translated:
(as Ganymede) Be patient for a bit longer while I go over the terms of our agreement. (to DUKE SENIOR ) You say that if I bring Rosalind here, you will give her to Orlando in marriage?
(as Ganymede)
to
)

paragraphs.original: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, even if I had whole kingdoms to give along with her.

paragraphs.original: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.
paragraphs.translated: I will, even if I were king of all kingdoms.

paragraphs.original: That will I, should I die the hour after.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, even if I die an hour later.

paragraphs.original:
But if you do refuse to marry me,
You'll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?
paragraphs.translated: But if you decide not to marry me, you'll marry this faithful shepherd instead?

paragraphs.original: So is the bargain.
paragraphs.translated: That's the deal.

paragraphs.original: Though to have her and death were both one thing.
paragraphs.translated: Even if marrying her meant I died.

paragraphs.original:
I have promised to make all this matter even.
Keep you your word, O duke, to give your daughter,
 - You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter.
 - Keep your word, Phoebe, that you'll marry me
Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd.
 - Keep your word, Silvius, that you'll marry her
If she refuse me. And from hence I go
To make these doubts all even.
paragraphs.translated: I've promised to make everything right. Duke Senior, keep your promise to give away your daughter. Orlando, keep your promise to marry his daughter. Phoebe, keep your promise to marry me, and to marry this shepherd if you choose to refuse me. Silvius, keep your promise to marry Phoebe if she refuses me. I'll leave now, to set all these things right.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA
paragraphs.translated: ROSALIND and CELIA exit.

paragraphs.original:
I do remember in this shepherd boy
Some lively touches of my daughter's favor.
paragraphs.translated: This shepherd boy reminds me quite vividly of my daughter.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born
And hath been tutored in the rudiments
Of many desperate studies by his uncle,
Whom he reports to be a great magician
Obscurèd in the circle of this forest.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, when I first saw him I thought he was your daughter's brother. But, my lord, this boy was born in the forest and has been schooled not in the usual subjects but only in magic. His uncle, who the boy says is a great magician and lives concealed within the boundaries of this forest, taught him.

paragraphs.original: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY
paragraphs.translated: TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY enter.

paragraphs.original: There is sure another flood toward, and these couples are coming to the ark. Here comes a pair of very strange beasts, which in all tongues are called fools.
paragraphs.translated:
Well, look: there must be another
flood coming, with these couples also on their way to Noah's ark. Here comes a pair of those strange creatures called "fools" in any language.
flood

paragraphs.original: Salutation and greeting to you all.
paragraphs.translated: Hello, and greetings to you all.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord, bid him welcome. This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest. He hath been a courtier, he swears.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, welcome this man. This is the jester I have met so many times in the forest. He swears he used to be a courtier.

paragraphs.original: If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation. I have trod a measure. I have flattered a lady. I have been politic with my friend, smooth with mine enemy. I have undone three tailors. I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.
paragraphs.translated: If anyone doubts this, let him put me on trial. I have danced a round, I have flattered a lady, I have been polite with my friends, smooth and cunning with my enemies. I have bankrupted three tailors. I have quarreled four times, and almost got in a fight.

paragraphs.original: And how was that ta'en up?
paragraphs.translated: And how was that one settled?

paragraphs.original: Faith, we met and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause.
paragraphs.translated: Well, we almost fought and then realized that we had reached the seventh cause.

paragraphs.original: How "seventh cause"? - Good my lord, like this fellow.
I like him very well.
paragraphs.translated: I like him very well.

paragraphs.original: God 'ild you, sir. I desire you of the like. I press in here, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, to swear and to forswear, according as marriage binds and blood breaks. A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favored thing, sir, but mine own. A poor humor of mine, sir, to take that that no man else will. Rich honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor house, as your pearl in your foul oyster.
paragraphs.translated: God bless you, sir. I want the same thing as all these other people. I've come here to be married, like all these other would-be couples. This poor virgin isn't much to look at, sir, but she's mine. It's a strange habit of mine to take the thing that no one else wants: virginity in an ugly girl is like a rich man living in a broken-down house or a pearl in the hideous oyster.

paragraphs.original: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.
paragraphs.translated: Really, he's very witty, and full of wise sayings.

paragraphs.original: According to the fool's bolt, sir, and such dulcet diseases.
paragraphs.translated: His wittiness, a sweet disease, is here one minute and gone the next, sir, as with most fools.

paragraphs.original: But for the seventh cause. How did you find the quarrel on the seventh cause?
paragraphs.translated: But back to that argument you mentioned. What's the "seventh cause"?

paragraphs.original: Upon a lie seven times removed. - Bear your body more seeming, Audrey. - As thus, sir: I did dislike the cut of a certain courtier's beard. He sent me word if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it was. This is called "the retort courteous." If I sent him word again it was not well cut, he would send me word he cut it to please himself. This is called "the quip modest." If again it was not well cut, he disabled my judgment. This is called "the reply churlish." If again it was not well cut, he would answer I spake not true. This is called "the reproof valiant." If again it was not well cut, he would say I lie. This is called "the countercheck quarrelsome," and so to "the lie circumstantial" and "the lie direct."
paragraphs.translated: Our argument went through seven stages - watch your posture, Audrey. - It went like this. I didn't like the way a particular courtier had cut his beard. He sent me word that, whether I liked it or not, he liked it fine. They call this "the courteous retort." If I repeat that it isn't cut well, and he responds that he isn't trying to please me, just himself, with his beard. They call this " the modest quip." If I say again it is poorly cut, and he responds that my judgment is no good, they call this "the sullen reply." If I say yet again that his beard is poorly cut, and he says that I'm not speaking the truth, they call this "the brave retort." One more time I say it's not well cut, and he says I'm lying. They call this "the argumentative countercheck." And so on through "the circumstantial lie" and "the direct lie."

paragraphs.original: And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
paragraphs.translated: And how many times did you say his beard wasn't cut well?

paragraphs.original: I durst go no further than the lie circumstantial, nor he durst not give me the lie direct, and so we measured swords and parted.
paragraphs.translated:
I didn't dare take it past "the circumstantial lie," and he didn't dare go to the "
direct lie," so we compared the lengths of our swords and then ended the fight.
direct lie

paragraphs.original: Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?
paragraphs.translated: Can you name the steps of that argument again?

paragraphs.original: O sir, we quarrel in print, by the book, as you have books for good manners. I will name you the degrees: the first, "the retort courteous"; the second, "the quip modest"; the third, "the reply churlish"; the fourth, "the reproof valiant"; the fifth, "the countercheque quarrelsome"; the sixth, "the lie with circumstance"; the seventh, "the lie direct." All these you may avoid but the lie direct, and you may avoid that, too, with an "if." I knew when seven justices could not take up a quarrel, but when the parties were met themselves, one of them thought but of an "if," as: "If you said so, then I said so." And they shook hands and swore brothers. Your "if" is the only peacemaker: much virtue in "if."
paragraphs.translated: Of course, sir. There are rulebooks for arguing just as there are rulebooks for manners. Here are the steps. First is "the courteous retort"; second, "the modest quip"; third, "the sullen reply"; fourth, "the valiant retort"; fifth, "the argumentative countercheck"; sixth, "the circumstantial lie"; seventh, "the direct lie." You can avoid getting to that final stage if you can properly use an "if." I once heard of an argument that seven judges couldn't settle. The two parties met up on their own, and one said, "Well, if you said this-and-that, then I must have said such-and-such," and they shook hands and parted on good terms. "If" is the only peacemaker. "If" is a very valuable word.

paragraphs.original: Is not this a rare fellow, my lord? He's as good at anything and yet a fool.
paragraphs.translated: Isn't he a remarkable fellow, my lord? He's as smart as they come, but just a jester.

paragraphs.original: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit.
paragraphs.translated: He uses his clownishness to disguise his deadly wit.

paragraphs.translated: JAQUES DE BOYS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Let me have audience for a word or two.
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
Addressed a mighty power, which were on foot
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here and put him to the sword.
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came,
Where, meeting with an old religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise and from the world,
His crown bequeathing to his banished brother,
And all their lands restored to them again
That were with him exiled. This to be true
I do engage my life.
paragraphs.translated: Let me have your attention for a moment. I'm Sir Rowland's middle son, and I bring you news. When Duke Frederick heard that great, worthy men were coming to this forest every day, he raised a large army to invade this land and fight his brother. But just at the edge of the forest, he met an old religious man. He spoke with him for a while and decided not only to abandon his pursuit of his brother but even to retreat from the world. He's giving the throne to his banished brother and restoring all the men he'd exiled to their rightful lands. I swear on my life that I'm speaking the truth.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome, young man.

And, after, every of this happy number
That have endured shrewd days and nights with us
Shall share the good of our returnèd fortune
According to the measure of their states.
Meantime, forget this new-fall'n dignity,
And fall into our rustic revelry.
 - Play, music. - And you brides and bridegrooms all,

paragraphs.translated: Welcome, young man: you bring a great present to your brothers' wedding. To Oliver, you return his lands; to Orlando, you give a whole dukedom, since he will inherit my land. But first, let's finish the things we started out here. Then I'll share the abundance of my returned fortune with all those that have stayed out here with me, according to the rank and status each of you enjoy. But until then, let's forget our nobility and enjoy some fun. Music, please. Brides and bridegrooms, dance your happiness away.

paragraphs.original: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue, but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs no bush, 'tis true that a good play needs no epilogue. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes, and good plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues. What a case am I in, then, that am neither a good epilogue nor cannot insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play. I am not furnished like a beggar; therefore to beg will not become me. My way is to conjure you, and I'll begin with the women. I charge you, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as much of this play as please you. And I charge you, O men, for the love you bear to women -  as I perceive by your simpering, none of you hates them -  that between you and the women the play may please. If I were a woman, I would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleased me, complexions that liked me, and breaths that I defied not. And I am sure as many as have good beards, or good faces, or sweet breaths will, for my kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
You don't usually see a woman deliver an epilogue, but it's no worse than seeing a man deliver the prologue. If it's true that you don't need
ivy to sell good wine, then it should also be true that a good play doesn't need an epilogue. But they use good-quality ivy to sell good wine, and a good play is improved by a good epilogue. But then I'm in a strange position, as I not only do not have a good epilogue, I'm not sure this was a good play. I'm not dressed like a beggar, so it wouldn't be becoming for me to beg. No, instead I'll bewitch you, and I'll start with the women. Women, in the name of the love you have for men, I demand that you like as much of this play as you feel like. Men, in the name of the women you love - and I can guess by your goofy smiles that none of you exactly hates them - the play will act as a nice toy for you and the
ladies to share. If I actually were a woman, I'd kiss all of you that have beards that pleased me, complexions that I liked, and breath that wasn't foul. And I'm sure that all of you with nice beards, good faces, and sweet breath will, when I curtsy good night, give me a nice round of applause.
